62. For a biographical profile on Delannoy, see Henry Poulaille, "Aristide Delannoy," in Henry Poullaile, Un crayon de combat: Aristide Delannoy (Nantes: Le Vent Du Ch'min, 1982), 5–13.

63. Ede, 66.

64. Ede, 84. Gaudier-Brzeska's 30th June letter, stating his intention to purchase a portrait print of Delannoy, provides us with further evidence of the role of Les Hommes du jour in his artistic and political formation. In the aftermath of Delannoy's death both Les Hommes du jour (27th May1911), and La Guerre sociale (24–30th May, 1911) announced the formation of a committee to organize a raffle of donated works of art in support of Delannoy's young widow, but it was Les Hommes du Jour alone that launched a further campaign on behalf of Delannoy's daughter Madeleine. The 27th May issue included an announcement that Gaston Raieter had agreed to produce a print of his death-bed portrait on "papier de luxe" for sale in support of Delannoy's "little girl": the cost of the print, with postage was "2 fr., 50," the exact amount cited by the sculptor. See, "Pour la veuve de Delannoy," Le Guerre sociale (24–30 May, 1911), 2; "Pour la Veuve de Delannoy" and "Pour Madeleine Delannoy," in Les Hommes du jour (27 May 1911).

65. For a concise summary of the "Delannoy Affair," see Robert Justin Goldstein, Censorship of Political Caricature in Nineteenth-Century France (London: The Kent State University Press, 1989), 254–57.

66. Douglas Porch, The Conquest of Morocco, 1903–1914 (New York: Knopf, 1983), 168–182.

67. Vilette, 218–231.

68. Goldstein, 255.

69. Ede, 212–13.

70. Goldstein, 255.

71. While the Press Law of July 1881 is recognized to have abolished most forms of censorship, it still authorized the prosecution of any writing or image deemed to have insulted key elements of the government, such as the presidency or the army. Justin Goldstein and Adolph Rosengarten have outlined cases in which this provision was used to harass writers and caricaturists engaged in political critique, including Delannoy, Grandjouan, and Méric. See Goldstein, 238–257 and Adolph G. Rosengarten, "The Evolution of French Military Power from 1872 to 1914," Military Affairs 45 (December 1981), 180–186.

72. Goldstein, 256.

73. Miguel Almereyda, "Notre Procès," Les Hommes du jour (3 October 1908); "En Prison!," Les Hommes du jour (6 March 1909); "Notre Procès," Les Hommes du jour (24 April 1909); "Mise en liberté," Les Hommes du jour (3 July 1909).

74. See for instance drawings reproduced in the following issues of Les Hommes du jour under the title "Une Saison à la Santé": 14 January 1911; 21 January 1911; and 12 March 1911.

75. Gaudier informed Sophie Brzeska of Delannoy's death May 14, 1911, the day after he read the May 13 issue of Les Hommes du jour announcing Delannoy's demise. See Ede, 66.

76. The articles for this issue included: Victor Méric, "Aristide Delannoy," "Aristide Delannoy et les Artistes (Steinlen, Willette, Poulbot, Rictus, Signac)," "Aristide Delannoy et la Presse," Henri Guilbeaux, "Hommage à Delannoy," "Quelques dessins de A. Delannoy, parus dans les 'Hommes du Jour'."

77. For discussion of this campaign, see n. 64. The notice mentioning Angrand, Luce, Signac, and Henri Matisse, among others is titled "Pour la Veuve de Delannoy," in Les Hommes du jour (2 December 1911).

78. O'Keeffe, 54–55.

79. Gaudier notation in his Blue Notebook; quoted in O'Keeffe, 97.

80. Sophie Brzeska, from her "Matka." ms., Cambridge University Library, cited in O'Keeffe, 118.

81. Gaudier to Sophie Brzeska (13 January 1912) in Ede, 116, cited in O'Keeffe, 107.

82. Brodzky, 77–78, cited in O'Keeffe, 119.

83. O'Keeffe, 119.

84. O'Keeffe, 138.

85. See the articles, dated from 1907 to 1911, collected under the section "Contre le Colonialisme" in Villette, 214–31; for an overview of La Guerre sociale's campaign against disciplinary battalions in North Africa, see Miller, 161–72.

86. Ede, 149.

87. Ede, 152–56. This ideological declaration—made to his lover Sophie Brzeska and to his immediate family—stands in stark contrast to the explanation apparently given to his patron, the retired military officer Haldane MacFall. In a letter to Horace Brodzky dated October 2, 1919, MacFall recalled that Gaudier "came to me one day saying that he was ignoring his calling up papers for the French army" because "he could not face two years lost to sculpture." "Well I went into it very seriously with him—told him it was a hideous thing for a French artist to cut himself off from France, above all from Paris… However he decided to desert. But the moment the war broke out… it found him too much a Frenchman to forsake his people." MacFall's statement not only attests to his lack of awareness of Gaudier's anarchist convictions, but likely indicates the careful manner in which Gaudier justified his actions for a patron he deemed hostile to his political beliefs. Gaudier evidently thought the noble calling of art, rather than anarchist anti-militarism, suitable justification for his refusal in enlist in the eyes of MacFall. "Letter from Haldane MacFall to Horace Brodzky, 2 October 1919," 86. DD., Box VI, National Art Library, Victoria and Albert Museum, London.

88. Ede, 154, cited in O'Keeffe, 140.

89. Miller, 58.

90. Ede in his book on Gaudier refers to "a long, revolutionary political letter" written to Dr Uhlemayr dated March 12, 1913, but does not reproduce its ideological content (Ede, 217). While working on Savage Messiah, Ede was able to draw on the Uhlemayr correspondence, but scholars have been unable to trace these documents and they are no longer on deposit at the Gaudier-Brzeska archives in Kettles Yard Gallery, University of Cambridge, or University of Essex, all of which hold Ede's papers. Roger Cole is apparently the last scholar to have made use of the original letters. His biography of Gaudier-Brzeska informs us that Uhlemayr had sent Ede a group of letters and cards from Gaudier, including drawings, which he asked to be returned to him. Cole however does not indicate how he gained access to this material or its present location. See Roger Cole, Gaudier-Brzeska: Artist and Myth (Bristol: Samson and Company, 1995), 12, 23, 37–41, 94, 224.

91. First hand accounts by Sophie Brzeska, D. L. Murray, and T.E. Hulme himself all attest to Hulme's impact on Gaudier's views on the possibility of war. For a summary of the events leading up to Gaudier's and Hulme's decision to enlist see Fergusson, 183–84; O'Keeffe, 252–265; and Secrétain, 256–260.

92. For a summation of Hervé's dramatic transformation, see Heuré, 191–204; and Miller, 190–200.

93. Gustave Hervé, "14 Juillet 1913," La Guerre sociale (9–15 July 1913), 1, cited in Miller, 193–94. For an analysis of Hervé's turn to Republicanism to counter the nationalism of the French Right, see Paul Mazgaj, The Action Française and Revolutionary Syndicalism, (Chapel Hill, N.C.: University of Chapel Hill Press, 1979), 200–209.

94. Miller, 192–94.

95. Hervé, cited in Miller, 201; and Heuré, 219.

96. Cited in Miller, 208–209. The Socialist Party and syndicalist unions enthusiastically entered into the union sacrée, with signs of a schism with the government only reappearing after 1916. See Roger Magraw, A History of the French Working Class, Volume II (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1992), 154–175.

97. Rudolph Rocker, The London Years, London, 1956, 247. See Gaudier-Brzeska's glowing reference to Kropotkin in n.3.

98. For a biography of Méric, see Jean Maitron, Dictionnaire biographique du movement ouvrier français, Volume XXXVI (Paris: Éditions Ouvrières, 1964–1997), 252–255.

99. The journal published pictures of the Cathedral before and after the German bombardment in Les Hommes du jour No. 348 (October 1914); number 351 (October 1914) contained another photograph, this time of the Cathedral interior; and the Christmas edition (No. 360, December 1914) showcased Paul Fort's poem, "La Cathédrale de Reims," labeling it a response on the part of a cultured Frenchman to "the crime that the Germans accomplished by this bombardment which dishonored and condemned Prussian militarism forever."

100. Romain Rolland, Au-dessus de la mélée (Paris: Ollendorff, 1915); cited in Kenneth E. Silver, Esprit de Corps: The Art of the Parisian Avant-Garde and the First World war, 1914–1925 (Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press, 1989), 7–8.

101. See for instance, Donald Drew Egbert, Social Radicalism in the Arts (New York: Knopf, 1970), 237–249; chapters two and three in John Hutton, Neo-Impressionism and the Search for Solid Ground: Art, Science and Anarchism in Fin-de-Siècle France (Baton Rouge: University of Louisiana Press, 1994); the chapter titled "Nos ancêstres les gaulois," in Eugen Weber, My France: Politics, Culture, Myth (London: Harvard University Press, 1991); chapter one of Elizabeth Emery and Laura Morowitz's book, Consuming the Past: The Medieval Revival in fin-de-siècle France (Aldershot: Ash-gate, 2003); and chapter four in Mark Antliff, Inventing Bergson: Cultural Politics and the Parisian Avant-Garde (Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press, 1993).

102. For an analysis of the appropriation of the coq gaulois as a revolutionary symbol by the French left, including members of the French commune, see Catherine S. Brosman, Visions of War in France: Fiction, Art, Ideology (Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1999), 32–33; for analyses of the importance of this symbol for French and Belgian anarchists affiliated with the Symbolists and Neo-Impressionists, see references to the journal Le Coq Rouge (1895–1897) in Eugenia Herbert, The Artist and Social Reform: France and Belgium, 1885–1898 (New Haven, C.T.: Yale University Press, 1961); and Anne Dymond, "A Politicized Pastoral: Signac and the Cultural Geography of Mediterranean France, Art Bulletin 85, no. 2 (June 2003): 363.

103. Catherine S. Brosman and Kenneth Silver have both documented the transformation of this symbol of populism into a widely deployed emblem of the common French soldier's "heroic" battle against Germany during World War One. See Brosman, 30, 32–33, 47, 57; and Silver, 44, 50.

104. The postcard, which is in the Ezra Pound papers at the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript library at Yale University, was sent to Pound by Gaudier on November 29, 1914. On the back Gaudier writes to thank Pound for sending him a sweater and a pack of cigarettes; he also notes that "we killed a German a few days ago." Paul O'Keeffe conjectures that Gaudier may have sent the postcard to Pound because the English caption concerning the French cock "must have been liable to vulgar innuendo" (O'Keeffe, 272); however given the ideological import of the Gallic rooster at this historical juncture that interpretation seems reductive and lacking in nuance. Gaudier sent another wartime postcard of the Cathedral, which pictured Reims before its destruction, to Katie Smith on May 29, 1915. On this postcard he noted that he was writing while "covered with earth" in the midst of an intense German bombardment. This postcard is included in the Gaudier Brzeska-Katie Smith correspondence at the Hyman Kreitman Research Center, housed at Tate Gallery Archive. See "Gaudier-Brzeska to Katie Smith, 1907–1915" (TGA 9115).

105. For a comprehensive account of the cultural codes defining acts of violence on the part of French males from the middle and upper classes, see Robert A. Nye, Masculinity and Male Codes of Honor in Modern France (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1993).

106. France, cited in Haine, 463. Haines refers to page 296 of Ralph Nevill's, Night Life: London and Paris (London: Cassell and Company, 1926) as the source for the Anatole France quote.

107. The debate over whether anarchist acts of violence were morally justified when directed toward an individual tyrant, but indefensible if enacted against an unjust society writ large, was an ongoing one in the anarchist press before 1914. Followers of the anarcho-communism of Peter Kro-potkin tended to endorse the former position, while proponents of the anarcho-individualism of Max Stirner defended indiscriminate acts of violence. For a succinct summation of this debate, see Niall Whelehan, "Political Violence and morality in anarchist theory and practice: Luigi Galleani and Peter Kropotkin in comparative perspective," Anarchist Studies 13, no. 2 : 147–168.

108. For an analysis of references to martyrdom, both visual and literary, in anarchist discourse, see Sonn, 165–66, 172–173, 263–289.

109. For an analysis of Georges Sorel's cultural politics as expressed in his Reflections on Violence and related writings, see Mark Antliff, Avant-Garde Fascism: The Mobilization of Myth, Art and Culture in France, 1909–1939 (Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press, 2007), 63–81.

110. "Ce n'est pas une guerre politique. Il s'agit de sauver la civilisation avant que ces salauds détruisent toutes les oeuvres d'Art." This quote is attributed to Gaudier-Brzeska by Sophia Brzeska, in her "Matka." ms., Cambridge University Library, sheet 173. Sophie Brzeska periodically labeled her manuscript numerically on the top left of a page, followed by a series of unnumbered pages. The quote is on the page immediately following that labeled sheet 173.
