Clark, 1686), 1, 68; Lithgow, The Totall Discourse, off the Rare Adventures, and Painful Peregrinations of Nineteen Long Years , 367; Josafa Barbaro and Ambrogio Contarini, Travels to Tana and Persia, trans. Lord Stanley (London: Hakluyt Society, 1873): 2.172 (Barbaro was in Persia in the 1470s); Tomé Pires, The Suma Oriental:An Account of the Est, from the Red Sea to Japan, Written . . . 1512-1515 (London: Hakluyt Society, 1944), 23; Chardin, Travels in Persia (1686; rpt. London: Argonaut, 1927), 242. Nicolas de Nicolay also comments that Persians "are so given to the detestable sine against nature, they take it for no shame" to be public about their predilections, having "places appointed and ordained" for its practice. See The Navigations into Turkie (London 1585; rpt. Amsterdam: Da Capo Press, 1968), 117.

11. Walter G. Andrews and Mehmet Kalpakli, The Age of Beloveds: Love and the Beloved in Early-Modern Ottoman and European Culture and Society (Durham: Duke University Press, 2005), 28. In addition to Afary, Njamabadi, and Amer, cited above, this ground-breaking scholarship includes Dror Ze'evi, Producing Desire: Changing Sexual Discourse in the Ottoman Middle East, 1500-1900 (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2006); Khalel El-Rouyeb, Before Homosexuality in the Arab-Islamic World, 1500-1800 (Chicago University Press, 2005); Joseph Massad, Desiring Arabs (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2007); and Kathryn Babayan and Njamabadi, eds., Islamicate Sexualities: Translations across Temporal Geographies of Desire (Cambridge: Harvard Middle Eastern Monographs, 2008). For years Everett Rowson has been researching homoeroticism in medieval Arabic literature with sophisticated results in a number of essays.

12. Particularly good on this point are Ze'evi, Andrews and Kalpachli, and El-Rouyeb.

13. For the specific form and development of the Arabic ghazal, see Robert Irwin, Night and Horses and the Desert, pp. 42-56, who gives examples of its rise and proliferation during "the great age of love poetry" flourishing in Damascus during the Umayyad dynasty. In "The Arabic Ghazal: Formal and Thematic Aspects of a Problematic Genre," in Ghazal as World Literature II: From a Literary Genre to a Great Tradition: The Ottoman Gazel in Context, ed. Angelika Neuwirth, Michael Hess, Judith Pfeiffer, and Borte Sagaster (Wurzburg: Ergon Verlag, 2006), Thomas Bauerk notes that by the ninth and tenth centuries the beloved is "almost certainly a male youth," as distinct from traditional nasib love poetry where the beloved is a girl. The Arabic ghazal was typically 5-12 lines, with a specific rhyme scheme and the author's penname, or Takhallus, embedded as word-play in the final line; the intent was less to create an original expression but evoke emotions that the audience would recognize and respond to through the manipulation and extension of a standard repertoire of images and situations. Franklin Lewis, "The Transformation of the Persian Ghazal: From Amatory Mood to Fixed Form," in Ghazal as World Literature, explains the metrics and thematics traditionally associated with the rubba'iyat and the evolution of the Persian ghazal from the Arabic original. See also Irwin, Night and Horses, on the merging of the khamriyya (poetic genre centered on the saki or wine-bearers) with the ghazal in the 'Abbasid dynasty, which established Baghdad as the center of court life, during which caliphate the Arab elite was very receptive to Persian influences, incorporating Persian genres and words into Arabic literary usage .

14. Ahmad al-Tifashī cites this lyric in his early-fourteenth-century erotic anthology The Delight of Hearts, trans. Edward A. Lacey (San Francisco: Gay Sunshine, 1998), 63.

15. Sema Nilgun Erdoǧan, Sexual Life in Ottoman Society (Istanbul: Donence, 1996), 92-3.

16. On the tradition of obscene, bawdy, and erotic genres as they developed first in Arabic and then Persian literatures, see Paul Sprachman. From the early medieval period, sokuf and mojun genres mixed ribald prose and poetry that, as Sprachman writes, delighted in being obscene, its themes typically that of "sodomy, pederasty, pimping, and adultery" (xiii). Obscene literature could either take the form of the bawdy (hazl), lampoons or "insult poetry" (hajv), or satire (tanz) (xxi-xxii).

17. Gazali (pen-name of Deli Birader, born Mehmed of Bursa), The Book That Repels Sorrows and Removes Anxieties, in Selim S. Kuru, A Sixteenth Century Scholar Deli Birader and his Dāfi'ü l-gumūm ve Rāfi'ü l-humūm (Harvard University, May 2000), 179. The translation is Kuru's Ph.D. thesis, accompanied with informative annotations, biographical, and bibliographical information.

18. On the rise of the genre in its Persian form, and its relation to the prior tradition of rubbaiyat written about youthful craftsmen, see Sunil Sharma, "Generic Innovations in Sayfī Buharai's Shahrashub Ghazals," in Ghazals in World Literature, 141-144. The basic feature of the şehrengiz (sharashub in its Persian form) is its at once humorous and complimentary "representation of the beloved as a youthful artisan or member of another social group having such marked features as to allow a poet to make fanciful allusions to this quality" (Sharma, quoting De Bruijn [1983:7], p.142). Noting that the şehrengiz had been popular in the Ottoman world since the poet Meshi (d. 1513), Jan Schmidt, The Joys of Philology: Studies in Ottoman Literature, History, and Orientalism (1500-1923), Vol. 1: Poetry, Historiography, Biography, and Autobiography (Istanbul: Isis Press, 2002), also points out that a central artistic amusement of such poetry was "the invention of puns on the names of the boys" being celebrated within the verse's metaphors and language, and that by the nineteenth-century, the format was "regularly suppressed by the Ottoman censor" for its homoerotic content (36, 38).

19. "There is no love until I am with my beloved in prison, / I drink wine daily so he can haul me off to prison." Quoted in Sharma .

20. Of this Janissary, one Kurd Bali, the poet writes:.

He burns with desire
As he batters his lover.
He is a brilliant Janissary,
With a slender re.
One can't resist his lips—
But it is arduous to get a kiss. Quoted in Erdoǧan

.

21. Translation of Andrews and Kalpackli, 41.

22. Schmidt, "Joys," 36-40.

23. Huban-name, lines 65, 57, 59; a translation of the original by Fatih Kursan, Ph.D. student at University of Chicago, with my emendations. Kursan collated manuscripts in the Baǧdatli Vehbi collection (no: 1618) and the H. Hüsnü Paşa collection (no. 1009) in the Suleymaniye Library (Istanbul), and the Yazma Baǧşlar manuscript (no. 4231. in Istanbul University Library). The Zenan-name has a similar frame, although, tellingly, the first European translator, Jean-Adolphe Decourdemanche, changed the gender of Fāżil's partner from male to female, thereby obscuring the homoerotic context that gives rise to its portraits of women. Schick, p. 181, also makes this point. The Zenan-name received much broader distribution than the Huban-name, undergoing at least four editions and being included in E. Powys Mathers's collection, Eastern Love, vol. 3 (London: John Rodker for Subscribers, 1928).

24. Le Livre des Beaux, par Fazyl Bey, Traduit du Turc par un Pachaq à Trois Queues ([1909] rpt. Fontfroide: Bibliothèques Artistique and Litteraire, 1996), n. p.; hereafter abbreviated LB. Translations from the French are my own. Along with Loti, Loüys, and Gide, the note mentions as a possible authorial candidate Edmond Fazy, author of La Nouvelle Sodome , whose style and content seem to me to have little in common with the "author" of Le Livre des Beaux.

25. "The book pretends, not very convincingly, to be the work of one Fazyl Bey, a contemporary of Louis XIV and Napoleon, translated by 'The Three-Legged Pasha'" with its intent to "satirise and perpetuate European erotic images of the East in the style of soft-core pornography." Aldrich, Colonialism and Homosexuality (London: Routledge, 2003), 111-12.

26. The only twentieth-century translation of the text into modern Turkish (expurgated) is Ercumend Muhib, Hubanname ve Zenanname (Istanbul: Yeni Sark Kitabevi, 1945). An earlier version appears to have been printed in Turkish in 1810.

27. (LB, 16; Aldrich, 12) Here, the anonymous author again reveals his knowledge of Middle Eastern poetic traditions: ghazal poetry typically includes clever puns on the author's "signature" or poetic name (takhallus) in the final line of the verse.

28. (LB, 16) As we shall also see in the case of Crowley, Burton res as a kind of patron saint among European homophiles, a reputation cemented by his essay, "The Sotadic Zone," which appears in the Volume 10 Appendix of Burton's 10 volume translation of The Book of a Thousand Nights and a Night (1885-88).

29. The original, line 171, does cite Abū Nuwās in context of the 'Abbasids; but the reference to the Nights, which reappears at the end of the French version, is the modern writer's interpolation. (Indeed, the reference to Nights might well be another clue to the European status of the anonymous author, since the work had fallen out of favor in Ottoman court circles for centuries, whereas it had been an overnight sensation in the West since its 1704 translation—the second best-selling book next to the Christian Bible).

30. See al-Tifashī, 129, where the youth from Homs, a Syrian city famous for its water mills, learns that his "shapely ass in Baghdad is a lot more profitable than a mill at Homs!" Compare to Fāżil Bey's text: "What counts here is the ass! Not the mill . . . what do you think the mill can yield compared to ass?" There is no reference to the death of the father or the summons home in Fāżil's version; in his variant, the boy's home is Kufe, a city in Iraq.

31. Homi K. Bhaba, "The Other Question," Screen 24.6 : 33.

32. (LB, 77) All the local color touches and on-the-scene immediacy are the modern author's fabrication; in the original, Fāżil concludes with ten couplets enumerating the various beautiful attributes of young Greeks with the line, "It is as if God has designed the most utterly perfect version of humankind!", which the modern writer adapts at the end of this quoted passage.

33. In the original Huban-name, the pun is purely linguistic, for here the boy mispronounces "shin" as "sin" ("sh" is written with three dots in the Arabic script while "s" has none), leading to the quip: "Do not think his pronouncing of shin as sin is a mistake, it is because there is no more place for dots in his mouth" (line 419). In Greek, there is little differentiation between "s" and "sh" sounds, with both represented by the letter sigma; thus Fāżil Bey is subtly playing on ethnic/national difference as well. Thanks to Fatih Kursun for his insights here. In the French text, however, the author makes the same pun on "sik" / penis in the very first portrait, of the beau of the Indies, who is identified as a "Sikh"—a footnote appears on the same page making sure we get the lewd joke. The fact that this portrait does not appear in the Huban-name underlines the degree to which the joke is the work of the modern creator.

34. In this dramatization, the modern author condenses a series of unrelated, scattered references in the original into a unified set-piece of his own creative imagination.

35. Orhan Pamuk, Istanbul: Memories and the City (London: Faber and Faber, 2005), 81.

36. Schick, The Erotic Margin, ch. 3, passim.

37. Ibid., 192-94.

38. Malek Alloula, The Colonial Harem (Minneapolis: Univeristy of Minnesota Press, 1986). Visual pornography, especially in the form of the erotic postcard, exploded in the 1880s and 1890s, according to Lisa Z. Sigel in "Filth in the Wrong People's Hands: Postcards and the Expansion of Pornography in Britain and the Atlantic World, 1880-1914," Journal of Social History 33.4 : 859-85. Although postcards showing genitalia were prohibited by the postal service, the censors in Britain applied a different set of criteria to those postcards purporting to represent "foreign" or "colonial subjects," which "even allowed images of naked men to pass if the subjects were 'natives'" .

39. What constitutes Von Gloeden's "kitsch" quality for Barthes is his indiscriminate mixing of codes of antiquity and present-day peasant boys without irony. See Barthes's untitled essay reprinted (orig. 1978) in Taormina: Wilhelm Von Gloeden, ed. Jack Woody (Santa Fe: Twelvetrees, 1997). Other critics, like Bruce Russell, "Wilhelm von Pluschow and Wilhelm von Gloeden: Two Photo Essays," Studies in Visual Communication 9.2 : 57-80, feel Barthes overlooks the degree of intention fueling Von Gloeden's compositional juxtapositions and his rejection of beaux-arts traditions. In celebrating Von Gloeden's queerness, Barthes simultaneously participates in Orientalist fantasies of otherness, fetishizing Sicilian boys' dark, almost "black" skin, "dirty peasant" hands, and (supposedly) "swollen" foreskins. See Russell, p. 62, for an apt critique of this aspect of Barthes' essay. See also the biographical commentary in Charles Leslie, Wilhelm Von Gloeden, Photographer: A Brief Introduction to his Life and Work (New York: Soho Photographic Publishers, 1977).

40. Gert Schiff, "The Sun of Taormina," review essay in The Print Collector's Newsletter 9.6 : 199. Jason Goldman comments on the surreptitious circulation of the more explicit images among Von Gloeden's contemporary clientele, then examines how these images have circulated in gay culture throughout the twentieth-century in "'The Golden Age of Gay Porn': Nostalgia and the Photography of Wilhelm von Gloeden," GLQ 12.2 : 237-58.

41. Intriguingly, Il Moro was also the nickname that Von Gloeden gave Pancrazio Bucini, the model who became his long-time lover and an eventual partner in his photographic enterprise. See Leslie, p. 50.

42. The former identification occurs in Thomas Waugh, Hard to Imagine: Gay Male Eroticism in Photography and Film from Their Beginnings to Stonewall (New York: Columbia UP, 1996). p. 51; the same model is identified as Tunisian without a date in James Gardiner, Who's a Pretty Boy, Then? One Hundred and Fifty Years of Gay Life in Pictures (Serpent's Tail, 1998), 21 ; Nicole Canet identifies the first as Tunis 1910 but similar poses by the same model as Tunis 1904 in Photographies orientalistes 1903-1930 (Paris: Galerie au Bonheur du Jour, 2004) and Tunis intime, portraits et nus 2904-1910 (Paris: Galerie au Bonheur du Jour, 2007). In all these photos, the seductive lure of the fantasized scenario is accomplished by the self-consciously crafted arrangement of the model's robes to reveal half—and just half—of his upper torso and a single nipple, thereby teasing the spectator to imagine the possibility of further divestiture. 20 heightens the homoerotic frisson by having the youth gaze directly into the camera, which fosters a fantasy of knowingness and intimacy, while his pose—one arm behind his head and the other cocked on his hip, jasmine blossom behind his ear— connotes a feminine receptivity without compromising his essential masculinity. In 21, the way in which the youth looks to the side, rather than into the camera, connotes a daydreaming state of mind that suggests an autoerotic fantasy; in other images, the model stands in front of a dark, grilled exterior, suggesting the mysterious depths from which he has emerged as well as the shadowy recesses in which an amorous encounter may follow.

43. See the biography by Lawrence Sutin, Do What Thou Wilt: A Life of Aleister Crowley (London: St Martin's Griffin, 2002) and Sandy Robertson, The Aleister Crowley Scraapbook (Berkshire, England: Quantum, 1988).

44. Publication history appears in Martin P. Starr's introduction to the first facsimile edition of The Scented Garden (Chicago: Teitan, 1991), 9-12; hereafter abbreviated SG.

45. (SG, 4) The Confessions of Aleister Crowley: An Autohagiography, ed. John Symonds and Kenneth Grant (New York: Hill and Wang, 1969), 451.

46. The title itself is a playful reference for those "in the know" to Nafzawi's medieval erotic treatise, The Glory of the Perfumed Garden; Sir Richard Burton was supposedly working on a translation of its chapters on homoerotic behavior when he died, a translation which his wife (again supposedly) burned. See the "Introduction" in the edition published in London by Neville Spearman, 1975, 8-10.

47. (SG, 8) In a humorous note to the clergyman's essay, Lutiy links art ("poetry"), Wilde, and homosexuality, claiming there is "no poetry in the panting Purita," then asking, "Is there better poetry in world than Wilde's[?]" Quoting Wilde on Hadrian and Antinous leads him into the following rhapsody: "to kiss my boy is a canzonet, and to suck him off a sonnet . . . to be beneath him is an epithalamium, and on top of him an epic" (SG, 34).

48. For example, when on p. 53 the editor glosses the line "lips like rotten bananas" as a probable "pun," he sets the nearly identical calligraphic scripts for the verb "kiss" and adjective "rotten" side by side.

49. As Crowley facetiously comments through Lutiy's voice in a footnote to poem 3, "El Haji more scandalously and obviously chooses the podex" as the "point of invisible unity" throughout "his masterpiece" rather than the beauty spot or black mole that usually serves this function in Sufi cipher.

50. Michael Berkowitz, "Rejecting Zion, Embracing the Orient: The Life and Death of Jacob Israel De Haan," in Orientalism and the Jews, eds. Ivan Davidson Kalmer and Derek Penslar (Tauber Institute for the Study of European Jewry Series, Waltham MA: Brandeis University Press, 2005), 11-14.

51. (De Haan, Kwatrinjnen, 77) Kwatrijnen has not been translated into English, and the translations given here are my own unless otherwise noted. Page numbers refer to the Dutch edition that may be found online at http://www.dbnl.org/auteurs/auteur.php?id=haan008; hereafter abbreviated K.

52. (K, 158) Another example where the holy city of Jerusalem is treated with profane irony is "Jeruzalem," in which De Haan contrasts Amsterdam, which "was my holy city," to Jerusalem, "a city full of secret streets" and "passionate people of alluring intensities," leading him to declare: "I've always loved beauty more than holiness" .

53. (K, 166; emphasis added) The stanza from which the notion of "wine, women, and song" is derived is XII in Fitzgerald's fifth edition of the Rubbiyat: "A Book of Verses underneath the Bough, / A Jug of Wine, a Loaf of Bread—and Thou . . . ."

54. (K, 47) My first line and a half follows Berkowitz's translation of this quatrain, p. 119. In De Haan's "Admonition" a similar triad of earthly pleasures combines, as in the great tradition of carpe diem lyrics, with the poet's desire to defy the inevitable passage of time and just "be" through love-making:

55. In "Backschisch," De Haan frankly acknowledges the economic underpinnings of his sexual forays, recalling the "sweet" boy in bare feet who "offer[s] his companionship" in return for "basheesh"—yet the boy's ability to "hang tough" or "hold his own," in De Haan's pun on the phrase, ons staan, demythologizes the persona's original projection of "sweetness" on this seasoned bargainer .

56. I use Richard Howard's translation, Amyntas: North African Journals (1906; rpt. NY: Ecco, 1988); hereafter abbreviated A.

57. André Gide, The Immoralist, trans. Richard Howard (1902; rpt. NY: Vintage, l970), 52.

58. (A, 16) The homoerotics with which Gide imbues North Africa is inseparable from the economic and colonial factors that made Algeria available to Gide. For a reading of the ambivalence in Gide's sexual/colonial politics, see Michael Lucey, Gide's Bent: Sexuality, Politics, Writing (New York: Oxford University Press, 1995). Analyzing Gide's account of his euphoric, initiatory sexual experiences in Algeria in the autobiography Si le grain ne muert, Lucey shows how the purity and egalitarianism Gide attributes to these encounters depends on his repressing their colonial underpinnings; the youth with whom he has his first sexual experience, Ali, is his hired servant, Mohammed's "petit corps sauvage" has been procured for Gide with Wilde's money. Certain of these less desirable reminders of the inequities built into the practice of "sexual tourism" are sidestepped, in Amyntas, the choice to homoeroticize sensation and environment rather than specific individuals or bodies; such re-framings forgo the occasion to analyze the socio-economic realities of colonialism, as Gide himself admits three decades later in a self-implicating statement where he confesses he was fully aware of the various social and economic inequities occasioned by colonial rule in the regions covered by Amyntas at the time he recorded his impressions, but decided issues like the "devious exportation of small Arab farmers" weren't his "cup of tea. I would have felt that as an artist it was beneath me to turn my pen to such vulgar concerns" (quoted in Lucey, 152). Jonathan Dollimore offers a short reading of Amyntas as a pastoral narrative of loss and self-recovery that veils the extent to which privilege and power facilitate Gide's appropriation of Africa's "otherness" for his artistic emergence in Sexual Dissidence: Augustine to Wilde, Freud to Foucault (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1991), 240-44. For more on sexual tourism and literary enclaves in the Mahgreb, see my "Vacation Cruises; or, The Homoerotics of Orientalism," PMLA 110 : 89-107.

59. Day's closeted homosexuality is assumed by art historians. See, for instance, Allen Ellenzwerg's chapter comparing the photographic work of Von Gloeden and Day in chapter 3 of The Homoerotic Photograph: Male Images from Durieu/Delacroix to Mapplethorpe (NY: Columbia University Press, 1992). The talented Giliberti, an openly gay artist of Tunisian heritage who lives in France, is also a novelist. His paintings are reproduced in Voyage Secret: Tunisie (Paris: Bonobo, 2004). My interviews with Giliberti (Paris 2006) confirm his deliberate blending of the homoerotic and indigenous to form a counter-colonialist visual response to Orientalist stereotypes of the "other." Day's homoerotic fascination with Arabic subjects is also apparent in his photographs of the teenaged émigré, Kahlil Gibran, a protégé and the eventual author of the best-selling The Prophet , whose prose-poetic imitations of Sufi poetry align him in interesting ways with "imitators" of the form like Burton and Crowley.

60. Such suggestive but simultaneously elliptical wording is similar to the rhetorical device of the anacoluthon that Roland Barthes locates in Loti's Aziyadé, in which ideas are introduced but never finish and "drift away." See Pierre Loti: Aziyadé,» in Le degré zéro de l'écriture suivi de nouveaux essais critiques (Paris: Seuil, 1972), 170-87. Emily Apter also cites this concept in her analysis of Michel's use of incomplete phrases that trail off in L'Immoralist, in which what is left unsaid "pre-res" the "unstated subtext of homoeroticism," in André Gide and the Codes of Homotextuality (Stanford: Stanford French and Italian Studies, 1987), 113-15.

61. (A, 106) Giliberti's evocatively titled painting, "L'entrée des contes" ("The threshold to stories"), reproduced as re 31, might be read as a counter-Orientalizing response by the very "other" that Gide is imagining behind that "black door"—but in Giliberti's version, this re has stepped out front to become a kind of watch-dog or guardian, and his direct gaze at the viewer both simultaneously challenges the Orientalist fantasy of entry and invites us to imagine the contes that unfold to those permitted to enter.

62. The legacy of Gide's modernist innovations in travel narrative can be traced in the Moroccan journal Roland Barthes included in his posthumously published volume, Incidents, trans. Richard Howard (Berkeley: Universtiy of California Press, 1992). Like Gide, Barthes renders his impressions in a series of fragmented, brief, verbal "snapshots" meant to evoke as much as describe. But unlike Gide, Barthes interweaves these textual impressions with descriptions of the various Tangier youths who catch his eye. In this regard, his technique recalls the serial erotic catalogues of Livre des Beaux, The Perfumed Garden, and Kwaitrains. In stark contrast to Gide's intensely affective engagement with North Africa, Barthes's narrative voice remains distant, coolly postmodern, as it reduces each boy to a few brushstrokes: each is fair game to be had in the vacation itinerary that traveling in Morocco offers Barthes. To grant these boys textual individuality would rob Barthes of the flaneur's frisson of exotic otherness, and himself of the colonialist's pleasure of enjoyment without guilt.

63. Thomas Dworzak, Taliban, with additional text by Jon Anderson and Thomas Reese (London: Trolley, 2003).

64. Sigel hypothesizes that in colonial postcards, the use of supplementary color or tints is meant to "accentuate the primitiveness of the scene . . . painted-on, primary colors suggest a primitive, uninhibited gaudiness" . While the idea is interesting, it may be an over-reading, since many turn-of-the-century photographs in America and elsewhere were tinted—some by the photographer, some at home—to "beautify" and "bring to life" the images. In the era of pre-color photography, and in situations where colorized photography is less affordable, tinting may have been a substitute that then became a style unto its own, not simply a "primitive" aesthetic. In the case of the tinted Lehnert and Landrock re pictured above, the colorization certainly adds to the sexualizing of the image by feminizing the boys, rouging their lips and cheeks.

65. Anderson, in the section of Taliban titled "After the Revolution," notes that "Afghans from other regions joke about the high incidence of pederasty among Kandahai men. They say that when the crows fly over Kandahar they clamp one wing over their bottom, just in case" (n.p.). Dworzak, writing of his experience of being routinely approached while on assignment in Afghanistan, writes that "If I had my balls grabbed by the soldiers (considered a neat chat-up line) in the north maybe once a week, in Kandahar it would happen daily. Soldiers there would tickle the palms of my hands; there were furtive caresses in crowds" ("In Downtown Kandahar," n. p.). In a Slate online podcast on Dworzak's project, Ahmed Rachid comments, "There is a very strong homosexual tradition in which an older man will . . . adopt a young man and become lover, become student, and teach him whatever skills he may have." Ironically, Mullah Omar's Taliban movement really caught fire, according to Rachid, when he attacked and killed a local warlord who had kidnapped young boys he was forcing to serve as his concubines. Thence Omar emerged as a kind of Robin Hood re protecting the poor against oppressive warlords. One of first things Mullah Omar did was ban homosexuality, but given long-standing tradition, it continued, albeit very surreptitiously. For a link to the Slate interview, see http://link.brightcove.com/services/player/bcpid271557392?bctid=1151557602.

For a recent PBS special (April 2010) on "Frontline" focused on "The Dancing Boys of Afghanistan" and the illicit sexual trade in boys undergirding this age-old practice, see http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/dancingboys/.

66. Dworak comments, in his defense, "I didn't take these pictures, I found them and want to make them public because I think they look great. A lot of people thought it was my way of representing the Taliban, that I went to Afghanistan, photographed the Taliban and made them look like Gilbert and George icons . . . So I got a lot of criticism in Europe from the liberal Left who found it demeaning for me to make them look like this." See the Slate interview cited in the prior note.

67. Jeff McMahonon, "The Painted Warriors of Kandhar," The Gay and Lesbian Review Worldwide 11.1 (Jan-Feb 2004).
