To further bolster Moore's rejection of Bryher's "fund," Mary Warner Moore wrote her daughter's admirer while in Seattle: "Is it not a reasonable thing for her to put back your keeping the beautiful 'scholarship' you conferred that memorable New York visit?" She adds of the projected "Syrian trip": "I wish that I had youth and health to throw myself into the breach to do for you just what I should so gladly do for Marianne, were she wishing to take the trip you are to take—that is, were you and she taking it together. But Marianne herself has no facility in that sort of forging forward—" (July 24, 1922; BL). The same infantilizing letter underscored that Bryher should not make "Marianne [her] personal conductor" and that "secretary work is back breaking" (this in reply to Bryher's off-hand somewhat absurd attempt to "employ" Moore if she could not get her to travel otherwise) and "hard for one so frail," concluding that Moore's job at the library with its four and half hour shift was "enough." Moore's mother acted as conductress here, blocking Bryher's manifold plots to have the Dactyl near her. These plots were foiled, yet the monetary layer in Bryher's courtship reflected (as it deflected) the erotic longing present in the pair's aesthetic exchange. Not every bone was buried without recovery.

In the same time frame of Bryher's intense entrancement with Moore between late 1920 and 1921 (underscored in Adventure and their correspondence), Bryher hoped matrimony would grant her the respectability she needed to go on with her queer ménage with H.D. and Perdita, giving her freedom from parental domination. Unhappily, she and McAlmon were treated poorly by the press, which reduced him to a fortune hunter, hanging on to Bryher as masculine benefactor traveling with a "wife" (H.D.), who had an illegitimate child and who was estranged from her husband. Even if she might have taken the marriage as a semi-affront considering the coincident courtship unfolding between herself and Bryher, none of the "queerness" of such an arrangement would have been lost on Moore. Moore's "Marriage" of 1923 reflects this, given that Bryher red as the provocative Eve ("so handsome /she gave me a start"). The poem appeared in Manikin, a journal brought out by Monroe Wheeler, who lived with Glenway Wescott in a "domestic" relationship. According to Moore, they were "able to maintain a relationship true to the spirit of marriage without the benefit of social contract" (BMM, 464). Further placing her within the fabric of the age of inversion, Moore (as Willis points out) drew upon Ellis's On Life and Sex in her depiction of marriage as "Crusade" both in letters to Bryher and H.D., and then in her poem "Marriage." (Again, as with Adventure, fact and fiction blur.)

Moreover, Moore wrote Bryher in 1922 with usual equivocation: "I like Havelock Ellis so much that I am perhaps too eager to find something new in what he writes . . . " Moore's associative eagerness is both occluding and revealing; in reading Ellis' injunction "to persevere," she thought of Trollope: "'for love that will gaze an eagle blind, that is a Hercules still climbing the trees in the garden of the Hesperides, forty-five to seventy is the best age. Up to that time men are merely flirting,' but perhaps that makes some seem willing to tease and I don't mean to be flippant" (March 22, 1922; BL). Is she suggesting here—or rather confessing—her own teasing disposition towards Bryher and affirming her commitment to bachelorhood? The quote from Trollope reappeared in "Marriage," thus situating Ellis as a mediating strand within Moore's inverted relationship to Bryher (with the respectable Trollope as screen). She thereby reasserted her defense of "merely flirting." Further, Moore was not naïve about lesbian pairings: Moore recommended, for instance, Stein's "Miss Furr and Miss Skeene," and in the same letter of 1923, expressed envy of Man Ray's photo of Bryher (to Bryher, July 5, 1923; SL, 200-1). She was also not naïve about her choice not to marry. However muted, she made several things clear: she had been flirting, she had been disappointed in Bryher's marriage, and she was a bachelor who had temporarily entertained the overtures of the butch shipping heiress. The strong erotic undertones in her letters to Bryher were finally abstracted in the poem "Marriage."

In this period, both Bryher and Moore (alone and together) crystallized and joined aesthetic with erotic goals; they reflected upon geographic and familial identity; they worried about publication as it hinged upon gender. Adventure itself commemorated Bryher's arc of arriving in America, meeting Moore, touring the country and then reuniting with the poet. Strikingly, Bryher would later repudiate Adventure turned West in 1925 (as if incorporating Moore's criticism of it as hurried, and then burying it); indeed, the book comes early in Bryher's writing career, yet the novel/memoir lucidly portrays Bryher taking Moore into her modernist imaginary and vice versa.53 At the same time, Bryher's relationship to Moore is an exercise in literary collaboration as transference.

The publication relationship presented in this article is a detail in a much larger cultural mosaic of Bryher's life as "female husband" to modernism; she is a kind of female Pound, considering her multilingual internationalism and multiple acts of shepherding other artists (other than H.D., Moore was the first "official" writer to whom Bryher offered a writing fund). When Pound visited H.D. in 1920 and found Bryher alone in their apartment, he pronounced her quite dull; she shared the same view of him. Moore recounted to her brother about Bryher's meeting Ezra: "Bryher said, 'I let him in; I thought it was the bread or the potatoes and I was very sorry I had. He talked to me an hour about a Saxon king and a Danish chief and how one wanted to carry off the other's wife and things went on till but one was left. He said afterward I didn't stand up very well without H.D'" (February 13, 1921; SL, 143; emphasis added). Pound's anecdote about the exchange of wives signals the patriarchal control artists like H.D., Moore and Bryher faced.

In November 1921, Moore wrote to H.D. and Bryher jointly regarding a review in the Nation, comparing herself to Edna St. Vincent Millay and Anna Wickham as women who "'contracted marriages with wit'" (as though contracting an illness) and "committed themselves to careers of brains"; "'Moore,' the critic continued, 'one admits right away, must best be taken for worse. She wedded wit, but after divorces from beauty and sense'" (to Hilda and Bryher, November 10, 1921; SL, 181-2). Moore's quotation from the review raises prominent questions about marriage and divorce in the modernist period. Unlike H.D. or Bryher who married for diverse reasons, Moore herself never married and lived with her mother after college as a kind of "couple" until Mary Warner Moore died in 1947. However, Moore was aroused by Bryher, and participated in a flirtatious attachment to the self-described "girl-page," a scenario that somewhat explains Moore's excessive disappointment in Bryher's marriage as well as her protective response—she worried that "it was an outrage for anyone to marry Winifred Bryher in such a style so unromantic" (to John Warner Moore, April 4, 1921; SL, 152). Moore saw through the compulsory convenience of the marriage, but probably could not fully sympathize with Bryher's capitulation to the "heterosexual/homosexual binary." The invocation of "marriages with wit" in the Nation review also suggests the way women writers, alone or unmarried, (or as Leavell frames it in Moore's case, celibate or committed to a mother/daughter relationship), are held accountable along the axis of heterosexual romance.

It is not surprising then that collaboration as a form of transference needs further refinement in cases where women (or men) do not fit within expected relationships; there are many degrees of affective and intellectual kinships forged where contracts are not available (nor even desirable) for solidifying them. In the case of Bryher and Moore, the literal encounters between them were brief, but their relationship was long and significant, layered and nautilus-like: they steadily corresponded, commented upon each other's writing, and wrote about each other (Moore wrote reviews of Bryher's novels in the 1950s and 1960s). By the late 1920s, Moore would accept a steady allowance (what Bryher referred to as "covenant") which kept Moore and her mother afloat through the Great Depression and beyond, up to Moore's death in 1972. Bryher also continued to send gifts, a stream of mad money for broaches, clothing, and other artifacts that caught Moore's eye. As further evidence of exchange, Bryher published Moore in her cinema journal Close Up (the poet reviewed, among other things, the lesbian 1930 cult classic, Maedchen in Uniform); Bryher would continue to take tips from Moore about films, discuss politics and mutual friends, visit her when in New York, but 1920-1923 remains the apex of their romantic collaboration.

The very concept of collaboration as transference I conclude demands refashioning to accommodate Bryher's modernist circle, of which Moore was central. Georgina Taylor has posited an "intersubjective" counter-public sphere that flourished among women modernists between 1913 and 1946 (with H.D. at the center) where "new ideas emerged through a process of interaction" primarily through the little magazines.54 Yet I suggest that even when "intersubjectivity" enters the question of collaboration, the homo-emotional and/or erotic dimension often goes missing, especially in cases like Bryher's—who often passes as only patron, rather than full-fledged collaborator; and in cases like Moore's—who is often dubbed asexual, with her poems fulfilling the Nation reviewer's implication that she suffers from lack of real conjugal union.

Bryher's transference with Moore reads like an attempt to act out an earlier self when being a boy seemed possible—a facsimile of frustrated longing she was still in the process of re-creating when she met Moore, who could allow her to act out her own male enterprising, testing the waters of her ability to express desire and take masculine roles outside her family. According to Schafer, the analyst in a transference scenario provides the "[c]ondition of the convincing, sustained readiness of those who are loved to contain one's more or less projective assaults on them, to tolerate the role of bad breast or phallus, arbitrary authority or violation of some other kind, and to endure being abandoned" ("Conditions for Loving," 408). Further, "having met this condition for loving, the analyst [again Moore and Bryher take turns in my case] is loved gratefully as a good mother, father, breast, womb, phallus, friend, and analyst. Not all at once, of course, and not once and for all, and not altogether, for this is only part of the work" ("Conditions for Loving," 408). Ambivalence and doubt are key to the work of transference, and in my mind, also to collaboration, where the old and new become "blurred, and "meaning is multifaceted"; we enter a territory where "one has found and accepted a new mode of experiencing one's self and one's world, which is to say, asserting a transformation to one's own subjectivity" ("Conditions for Loving," 409, 415).

Building upon Freud's notion of creating a new "edition" of the self, transformation takes place, according to Schafer, through the "psychology of metaphor," where some experiences can only be expressed metaphorically. In poems as in collaborative transference, "[m]etaphor is a new experience rather than a mere paraphrase of an already fully constituted experience. The metaphor creates an experience that one has never had before. It is an experience one has not realized by oneself. . . . it is a creation rather than a mere paraphrase or new edition" ("Conditions for Loving," 415). Metaphor—in the exchange between Bryher and Moore—was loaded: Bryher becomes Moore's publisher, her father, her rescuer, her child, her super-ego, her comrade, her usurper, even her seducer (and vice versa), across the course of their most intense interactions. Moore is Pterodactyl of the fish age, and Bryher is overweening adventurer who needs reining in; later, Moore's "edition" of Poems, turns into an assault that tests the limits of love, which appears to survive, even while the tenor of it necessarily changed. For Bryher and Moore, money and gifts became metaphoric monikers of personal and poetic value: can money transcend value of self or creativity? Can one "take" a gift without shame? Can one give it without shame? Can Bryher give it as a means of identification with her powerful shipping magnate father, and then transform this identity within the context of Moore's measures and gratitude? Can one gain purchase over the intangibles of an erotic connection, amidst the swirl of indeterminate nomenclature of female bachelors, of inverts, of queers? Transference, as I redefine it, is a kind of collaboration where "reference" travels between selves, and is not confined to a single text or "edition." In this essay's close up of Bryher's early "coercion" and urging of Moore, her writing Adventure and wanting to have it too, along with Moore's little-known promotion of the book, begin to elucidate the projections, introjections and subtle intimacies of modernist collaboration as transference.

Susan McCabe  

Susan McCabe is Professor of English at the University of Southern California, Los Angeles. She has published Elizabeth Bishop: Her Poetics of Loss and Cinematic Modernism: Modern Poetry and Film (Cambridge UP, 2005). Her book of poems Descartes' Nightmare won the Agha Shahid Ali Award (University of Utah Press, 2008). She is currently working on a literary biography of Bryher, "The Female Husband of Modernism."

Notes

1. Wayne Koestenbaum, Double Talk: The Erotics of Male Literary Collaboration (New York: Routledge, 1989), 139.

2. Ibid., 128.

3. It is, of course, impossible to sustain the idea of the artist working in complete solitude as a model for most modernist practice. It is now more common to think of networks—like the spidery mesh of lines (rather than neat family trees of lineage) in Bonnie Kime Scott's Gender of Modernism, linking peripheral and canonical writers.

4. Heather Love, Feeling Backward: Loss and the Politics of Queer History (Cambridge: Harvard University Press 2007), 77.

5. Ibid., 78.

6. Jayne E. Marek, Women Editing Modernism: 'Little Magazines & Literary History (Lexington: The University Press of Kentucky, 1995), 101.

7. Bryher to H.D., March 20, 1919; Bryher Papers, Beinecke Rare Manuscript and Book Library, Yale University; hereafter abbreviated as BL.

8. Barbara Guest's groundbreaking biography of H.D., Herself Defined: The Poet H.D. and Her World (New York: Doubleday, 1984), was instrumental in introducing Bryher into the critical scene, but often, in spite of itself, the book belittles Bryher's importance as lover, supporter, companion, collaborator, perhaps understandable in its effort to raise H.D.'s stature in the canon in the early 1980s when H.D. was herself eclipsed. As to Bryher's primary role in the journals she engineered and edited, she did participate in her own erasure by making sure others received more credit: in the instance of Close Up, she gave Macpherson centrality, though creating the first film journal in English was certainly the brain-child of both Bryher and Macpherson; with Life & Letters, she occluded herself almost entirely, although Moore, for instance, herself wrote the emerging poet Elizabeth Bishop to send her manuscripts directly to Mrs. Macpherson (September 8, 1935; SL, 353). The editor in chief of Life & Letters, appointed by Bryher, was Robert Herring, and he certainly deserves much credit; at the same time, Bryher asked her name not to be on the masthead although she worked closely with Herring in his selections.

9. Susan McCabe, "Bryher's Archives: Modernism and The Melancholy of Money," in English Now. Selected Papers from the 20th IAUPE Conference, ed. Marianne Thormählen (Lund, Sweden: Lund University Press 2008). Bryher was in analysis with Hanns Sachs from the mid-twenties up through his death in 1947. Bryher sent H.D. to Freud for analysis for sessions in 1933 and 1934, studied to be a lay-analyst, immersed herself in the period's psychoanalytic writings and attended psychoanalytic congresses. Thus, Bryher's relationships must be considered in light of her own sense of the overwhelming cultural significance of psychoanalysis. H.D. had certainly read Freud before meeting Bryher; likewise, Bryher knew Freud's work well before meeting Moore. Moore, on the other hand, didn't have any great faith in psychoanalysis. Still the language of projection, transference, and the incipient field of object relations, inspired by Freud and expanded through James Strachey and Anna Freud up to contemporary theorists like Jessica Benjamin, are useful in thinking about Moore and her modernist circle.

10. Judith Halberstam, Female Masculinity (Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press, 1998).

11. I am currently writing a critical biography, Bryher: Female Husband of Modernism.

12. Cristanne Miller, The Cultures of Modernism: Marianne Moore, Mina Loy and Elsa Lasker-Schüler (Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press, 2005).

13. Love, Feeling Backward, 78.

14. Macpherson, "As Is" in Close Up, Vol. VII No. 5 (November 1930), 296. He writes: "the film unit, or, in this case, film strip, or scene, cannot be thought of as a static quantity. Its essential character is transferential." The term, inspired by psychoanalysis, does not technically mean the same "thing," yet Macpherson, Bryher and H.D. were inspired by the ideas of transference. Borderline is primarily concerned with the dynamics of transferring and projecting disowned psychic material; the white characters, in particular, wish to deposit their unclaimed conflicts upon the film's black couple.

15. Sigmund Freud, "The Dynamics of Transference" in Essential Papers on Transference, ed. Aaron H. Esman (New York: New York University Press, 1990), 28.

16. James Strachey, "The Nature of the Therapeutic Action of Psycho-Analysis" in Essential Papers of Transference, 52; hereafter abbreviated "Therapeutic Action."

17. Sigmund Freud, "Fragment of the analysis of a case of hysteria" in Essential Papers on Transference, 3.

18. Roy Schafer, "Transference and the Conditions for Loving" in Essential Papers on Transference, 402; hereafter abbreviated "Conditions for Loving."

19. Freud, "Observations on transference-love" . Quoted in Schafer "Conditions for Loving," 404.

20. "[A]esthetic domestic conjunction" is Karin Cope's excellent description of the modernist collaboration between Stein and Toklas; I modify the phrasing here, but owe much inspiration to Passionate Collaborations: Learning to Live With Gertrude Stein (Victoria, B.C.: ELS Editions, 2005), 13.

21. Bryher, West (London: Jonathan Cape, 1925); citations will use page numbers from the renamed text, but will be referred to as Adventure throughout to denote the title as Moore knew it.

22. Pamela White Hadas, Marianne Moore: Poet of Affection (New York: Syracuse University Press, 1977), 5.

23. These overtly erotic poems from Arrow Music were all published in Poetry in December 1920 in Volume 17: "Wild Rose," "Eros," "Blue Sleep," and "Hellenics." They can be read as having in mind either H.D.—or if one credits Bryher's purported haste in composition—the just-met Moore.

24. Patricia Willis, "A Modernist Epithalamium: Marianne Moore's 'Marriage'," Paideuma 32, 2003: 265-297.

25. Elizabeth Young, "The Collage of 'Marriage': Marianne Moore's Formal and Cultural Critique" in Mosaic Vol. 26, No. 4., 107.

26. Bonnie Costello, Marianne Moore: Imaginary Possessions (Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 1981), 61.

27. Carolyn Burke, "'Getting Spliced': Modernism and Sexual Difference," in American Quarterly 39.1 : 98-121.

28. The first appearance of "The Fish" was in The Egoist 7.5 (August 1918): 95, as cited in Robin G. Schulze, Becoming Marianne Moore: The Early Poems, 1907-1924 (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2002), 464; hereafter abbreviated BMM. H.D. had already described Moore as "perfect craftsman," comparing her poetry to "bell-notes, like notes from some palace-bell carved beneath the sea" in "Marianne Moore," Egoist 3.8 (August 1916): 118.

29. Bryher, "My Introduction to America," Life and Letters To-Day 26 (Sept. 1940): 237.

30. From a typescript of the poem in Box 91, folder 3361 (BL).

31. Moore to Bryher, November 29, 1920; Selected Letters, eds. Bonnie Costello, Celeste Goodridge, and Cristanne Miller (New York: Penguin Books, 1997); hereafter abbreviated as SL. November 29,1920; SL 136.

32. This is important given Perdita's important role in her triangle with two mothers. The manuscript of the "unpublished autobiography" is at the Beinecke library in Box 46, Folders 1161-1165. Thanks to Julie Vandivere for guiding me to this text. In this work, Perdita expresses her own desire as a young child to think herself into becoming a boy.

33. Lowell to Bryher, 7 January 1919; Amy Lowell Papers, Houghton Library, Harvard University.

34. Linda Leavell, "Marianne Moore, The James Family, and the Politics of Celibacy" in Twentieth Century Literature (Summer 2003): 222.

35. Bryher to Moore, 24 September 1920; Marianne Moore Papers, Rosenbach Museum and Library, Philadelphia; hereafter abbreviated RML.

36. Anyone familiar with the archives of Moore or Bryher knows how prodigious their letters were; we are lucky to have Moore's Selected Letters, and the hefty volume covering just 1932-4, when H.D. was in analysis with Freud (Analyzing Freud: Letters of H.D., Bryher and Their Circle, ed. Susan Stanford Friedman [New York: New Directions, 2002]). As the editors of Moore's Selected Letters make clear, the meeting and subsequent correspondence with Bryher is "one of the highlights of this period" and that "[d]uring the early twenties it was not uncommon for them to exchange two to three letters every month" .

37. Bryher, The Heart to Artemis: A Writer's Memoirs (New York: Harcourt, Brace & World, Inc, 1962), 118.

38. This novel is also Bryher's contribution to a growing body of roman à clef in modernism; her published "trilogy" (Development, West, Two Selves) has received far less attention than H.D.'s posthumously published works of this sort. For instance, Paint it Today (composed in 1921), among the many autobiographical novels H.D. wrote but did not publish in her lifetime and was in fact marked "DESTROY," explores the poet's shift away from Pound (her "erstwhile fiancé") to Frances Gregg (H.D.'s first female love) and then to Bryher ("with eyes too intense for this generation, with bare feet too perfect, with slight arms too delicate, for all their wiry play of nervous tendons," 71). Edited by Cassandra Laity (New York: New York University Press, 1992).

39. Joanne Winning, ed., Bryher: Two Novels: Development and Two Selves (Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press, 2000), 24. See Winning's introduction for a summary of the many reviews Development received, among them the Times Literary Supplement's complaint that it was not a novel (xix).

40. Patricia Willis, ed., The Complete Prose of Marianne Moore (New York: Viking Penguin, 1986), 60-2.

41. Ibid., 61.

42. Bryher to Moore, Hotel Encanto, Santa Barbara; September 24, 1920; RML.

43. Willis's "A Modernist Epithalamium" in Paideuma 32.1-2-3 refers to this echo as well, 275.

44. H.D. compiled in her scrapbook a number of nude photographs of herself and Bryher from this period, with each of them in Hellenic poses against the backdrop of the wild sea.

45. "Mary Pickford in California," Box 91 folder 3358, BL; the journal bears the date of December 25, 1920. I haven't yet been able to locate the paper's name. In this piece, Bryher writes that film was then her "aversion of aversions" but concludes: "I am glad I have actually seen a film in the process of being made."

46. After Bryher's marriage to McAlmon, Bryher gets more attention and publicity from the press than had she not married. The headlines called attention to the queerness of her female companion (H.D.), the model turned poet (McAlmon) calling him in many articles a fortune hunter, and casting her as the mannish Winifred. The articles hint rather loudly at the threesome's queerness.

47. Willis, "Modernist Epithalamium," 276.

48. Fencing becomes an important element in Bryher's Two Selves where she writes: "Fencing was a world leading to freedom. Men always wanted to keep the best things to themselves" and then a few pages later: "Only when she could sit in her fencing breeches and read did she feel at ease" (206, 210).

49. Guest, Herself Defined, 188.

50. Cyrena N. Pondrom, "Marianne Moore and H.D.: Female Community and Poetic Achievement," in Marianne Moore: Woman and Poet, ed. Patricia Willis (Orono, Maine: National Poetry Foundation, 1990), 384.

51. Quoted by Harriet Monroe, "A Sympopsium on Marianne Moore" in Poetry Volume XIX, No. IV (January 1922): 208-216.

52. See Kathryn R. Kent's analysis of this poem in Making Girls into Women: American Women's Writing and the Rise of Lesbian Identity (Durham: Duke University Press, 2003). Kent traces the complex eroticism of Moore's relationship to her mother and family.

53. She writes, for instance, to Norman Pearson: "I was most ashamed of West—it ought to have been suppressed and somebody should have smacked me. I simply was knocked out by California and I had imagined it to be a sort of mountain Switzerland where one went on long walks in a nice climate. I did not go to movies in youth and was quite unprepared for Mary Pickford" (May 31, 1949; BL).

54. Georgina Taylor, H.D. and the Public Sphere of Modernist Women Writers, 1913-1946 (New York: Oxford University Press, 2001), 5.

Project MUSE Journals Volume 17, Number 3, September 2010 Forster and Liberace; or, The Invert's Tale

Volume 17, Number 3, September 2010

E-ISSN: 1080-6601 Print ISSN: 1071-6068

Forster and Liberace; or, The Invert's Tale
Wendy Moffat

Five years ago, reading in the E. M. Forster papers in the King's College Archive Centre at Cambridge, I came across a scrap of manuscript from the late 1950s, composed when the British novelist was almost eighty. The catalogue title was "Notes on the Future of Civilisation."1 Even in old age Forster remained a notably public re, commenting on nuclear proliferation, British policy toward India, post-war suburban planning, and the role of the arts in society. Until 1959 he reviewed books for the BBC magazine the Listener, where his close friend J. R. Ackerley served as literary editor. So when I opened the manuscript, I did not expect Forster's thoughts on the future of civilization to concern Liberace. But here was the American showman, described in Forster's spidery hand—Liberace and his "horrid" piano. Forster described "[f]emale teenagers" touching Liberace's clothes "as if they were the hem of the garments of Christ. Take care they don't tear you to pieces."2 The old man was clearly fascinated and repelled by the pianist, who first played concerts in Britain in the summer of 1956.

Until I saw them on the page together, Forster and Liberace seemed to occupy wholly separate conceptual spaces. Forster, the Edwardian, the buttoned-up Englishman, published his last novel A Passage to India in 1924, when Liberace was just five. Wladziu Valentino Liberace, the self-styled "simple boy from Milwaukee," by this time had perfected his extravagant persona—the white fur coat over the dazzling, rhinestone-encrusted white tie and tails, the towering candelabrum as a camp homage to Chopin, and the swimming pool in the shape of a grand piano.3 But here were their lives momentarily intertwined.

The thread of this queer narrative led me to the discovery of a political turn in Forster's private life. Forster collected a vast archive of his gay life, which he hid with exquisite caution, recorded with exacting precision, and deliberately preserved for gay posterity. There is no record that the two men ever met. But the Liberace allusion in Forster's private musing opens a new chapter in Forster's long, queer, modern life. For Liberace was legible to Forster and his friends. And Liberace's actions offered a concrete vision of "the future of civilisation" for these gay men.

Everything about Liberace's first international tour was designed to magnify his celebrity. Already a fixture on BBC television, he played Paris and Monaco; with his mother and brother, he attended a special audience with Pope Pius XII at the Vatican. He sailed to England aboard the luxurious Queen Mary and commissioned his own private train—"The Liberace Special"—to transport him from Southampton to Waterloo station. He drew fans from all social classes—selling out the Royal Albert Hall, the huge vaudeville-palace of the Palladium, and elegant supper clubs. Everywhere he faced a melee of fans. The Metropolitan Police had to lay on a whole separate squad for his protection. The music critics were less awful than one might expect. Despite the "circus-turn and the fancy-dress parade," some reviewers had to admit that Liberace had mastered a florid version of the Romantic repertoire (LAA, 193, 190).

In coming to England Liberace appeared to be recapitulating the successful ascendency to stardom he had begun in the United States. But the tour was a deliberate escape, designed to distract from a welter of accusations that the thirty-nine-year-old entertainer was not only homosexual, but also a predatory seducer of young straight men. A series of tabloid stories suggesting he was "Mad about the Boy" and the failure of his first film had cut into his ticket sales.4

Forster could have told Liberace that post-war London was not the refuge he imagined it might be. For gay men, the Blitz had been a time of remarkable freedom—paradoxically, despite the heightened atmosphere of security, so much could be hidden in a blackout. Forster, and many of his friends—who were a generation younger—cruised the streets of the city. Then, in the immortal words of Quentin Crisp, "Peace broke out."5

By the early 1950s, the British government began a crackdown on sexual license. The tabloids echoed the lament of Viscount Samuel in the House of Lords, who decried the "insidious poisoning" of Britain's "moral state," complaining "the vices of Sodom and Gomorrah, of the Cities of the Plain, appear to be rife among us."6 To curb this scourge, police agents-provocateurs were sent out to entrap homosexuals through solicitation; a special division of the Metropolitan Police was formed solely to patrol public urinals. The number of prosecutions for homosexual offenses skyrocketed.7

The press fanned this moral crusade in tones both salacious and indignant. Powerful and famous men were paraded as examples, including the recently knighted actor Sir John Gielgud and a Labour MP, who were arrested for cottaging. In the sensational Montagu case, three prominent men—including a young peer and the chief diplomatic correspondent for the Daily Mail—were charged with conspiring to commit indecency; the timing of the arrests was orchestrated by the police so the story could appear prominently on the front pages of the Sunday newspapers.8 Newspapers were in a race to outdo each other in reporting on sex while spinning out contradictory stereotypes about sexual criminals with increasing certainty and fervor. In May of 1952 the Sunday Pictorial devoted a full-page feature to ways to recognize these "Evil Men"; nine years later it helpfully explained "How to Spot a Homo."9 Readers could discern a homosexual by his sedate tweed jacket, suede shoes, and pipe, or alternately by his telltale effeminate manner and mincing step. These "exposés" reflected the anxieties born of the paradox that homosexuals, forced to live a double life, proved to be quite successful at it.

Forster was one of those men. He was sixteen in 1895 when Oscar Wilde was sent to prison for gross indecency. All his life he had lived cautiously as a closeted homosexual. In his old age Forster began to rethink this posture. He wrote a friend "The older one grows, the less one values secrecy perhaps, anyhow there is very little of me that I feel worthwhile to lock up."10 Now, 60 years after Wilde's conviction, Forster sent a copy of a letter he had published asking for "less social stigma" towards homosexuals to Lord Samuel, as a kind of catnip. The Viscount took the bait. "Incomprehensible and utterly disgusting as [homosexuality] appears to all normal people," Lord Samuel replied to Forster, "it seems to have the capacity to form a habit as potent as alcohol or narcotics."11 The law that was used to convict Wilde was still on the books when Liberace arrived in London.

Enter Cassandra—in this case the dire penname of William Connor, a gossip columnist for the Daily Mirror. The frenzied fan-worship drew Cassandra's ire. The day after Liberace arrived in London, before he had played even a single concert, Connor diagnosed a cultural malady in tones of hysterical invective. He was "appalled" and "terrified":

[Liberace] is the summit of sex—Masculine, Feminine and Neuter. Everything that He, She and It can ever want. . . . This deadly, winking, sniggering, snuggling, chromium-plated, scent-impregnated, luminous, quivering, giggling, fruit-flavoured, mincing, ice-covered heap of mother love has had the biggest reception and impact on London since Charlie Chaplin arrived . . . There must be something wrong with us that our teenagers longing for sex and our middle-aged matrons fed up with sex alike should fall for such a sugary mountain of jingling claptrap wrapped up in such a preposterous clown.12

Reading these words, Liberace construed that he was being accused of effeminacy and homosexuality. He rightly concluded that the stigma would threaten his career. "He, She and It"—he later said—"was the passage that decided me to sue. That was the one I was afraid would haunt me all my life" (LAA, 226). Like Oscar Wilde, Liberace brought a civil case of libel. It would be three years before the case came to trial, in the summer of 1959.

A counter-narrative about the relation between sexual attitudes and the future of civilization was developing, at first in private, in Britain during these years. On the 15th of September 1954, the Home Office appointed a committee of clergy, peers, and respectable academics to investigate the twin problems of female prostitution and male homosexuality. This became the Wolfenden Committee, named after the educator Sir John Wolfenden, which would recommend three years later that "homosexual activity between consenting adults over the age of twenty-one in private be no longer a criminal offense."13 It took almost another decade to enact these recommendations into law, and even then the statute was "mild and aetiolated."14 Even in the mid-1960s, the vaunted milestone in homosexual rights was largely symbolic.15

It is not customary to see Forster as a champion of gay rights, but the archives reveal that during this period he made several feints in the direction of public advocacy. During the committee's deliberations, Forster had a quiet, and heretofore unrecorded, luncheon with Sir John Wolfenden, during which he outed himself. Forster came away impressed, but not sanguine about the prospect of true reform. He composed a letter (published under a friend's signature) protesting a horrifying case in Abergavenny, Wales; a gay sting, which sent eighteen men to prison for twelve years—one attempted suicide, and a nineteen-year-old walked in front of a train.16 Later, Forster published a letter in the Times protesting the treatment of a gay seventeen-year-old boy from Consett, Durham who, denied bail though his family had raised the money, committed suicide as he awaited trial.17 Forster also donated £500, a huge sum, to the Homosexual Law Reform Society, dryly noting in his diary that he did not expect to see much return on his investment.

Sometimes the police crackdowns came very close to home. His close friend Mattei Radev was arrested for cottaging, and Forster contemplated testifying on his behalf and outing himself. A second scare came on the heels of the first, when a police raid on a Soho club (fetchingly named the "Mousehole") caused J. R. Ackerley to caution Forster against frequenting it until the scandal blew over.18 Indignant about the "Mousehole" raid, Forster persuaded Ackerley to write a letter in protest, cagily appropriating a neutral subject position:

Be frisky, but not 'we homosexuals' nor so much about yourself, lest it humourlessly be brought against you. 'I have occasionally drawn a cup of coffee at the Mousehole myself little knowing of my peril, or that a policeman might be observing me and might demand my name and address because my taste in clothes differed from his'—is about the level.

(Letter to J.R. Ackerly [circa January 1958])19

Liberace's trial in the summer of 1959 was front-page news. For two weeks in June the Times, to which Forster subscribed, reprinted column upon column of verbatim testimony. In the courtroom Liberace almost appeared to be following Forster's advice, disguised as the comically understated version of a "normal" man. Setting aside the white tails and rhinestones for a grey flannel suit, Liberace testified that Cassandra's words had attacked his manhood, made his mother ill, and "cost me many years of my professional career by implying that I am a homosexual. . . . It has caused untold agonies . . . and made me the subject of ridicule" (LAA, 228). On direct examination Liberace lied, as Wilde had done, saying he was not homosexual, nor had engaged in homosexual practices. He persuasively wrapped himself in the mantle of family values. He testified that, "My feelings [about homosexuality] are the same as anybody else's. I am against the practice because it offends convention and offends society."20

Liberace's case depended on the very cultural ideology about masculinity that the tabloids had reinforced in their endless articles on "gay-watching." Occasionally, reliance on these unexamined assumptions had the unintentional effect of queering every aspect of upper-class Britain. Sir Gilbert Beyfus, QC for Liberace's case, argued at the outset that Liberace's "elaborate wardrobe of what may be called fancy-dress" did not signify anything about the performer's masculinity:

Before we jeer at the American public for enjoying this added glamour or at Liberace for acceding to it, it is well to remember that less than 150 years ago, in the Regency period, our men dressed up and one of the greatest arts was that of tying a necktie. In these days of somewhat drab and dreary male clothing, remember the guards at Buckingham Palace, the Horse Guards in Whitehall, the Beefeaters at the Tower, the uniforms of the Privy Councillors at a Levée, Knights of the Garter and Peers of the Realm at the opening of Parliament. Look at the hunt ball when tough hunting men prance around in pink coats with silk lapels of different colours. Some add dignity, all add glamour.

He continued, importuning Mr. Justice Salmon to

Look at me, my Lord, and my learned friends, dressed in accordance with old traditions, which lends dignity to our proceedings. Because we dress like this here, it does not mean we dress like this in our ordinary daily life, nor does Liberace.21

Indeed, Ackerley and his friends had made quite a study of "remembering the guards at Whitehall," regaling Forster with stories of cruising handsome young men in uniform. Archives from Texas to the north of England contain colorful correspondence in a camp vein. Forster himself found this sort of humor infectious, once remarking that he had caught the poet William Plomer in an "unguardeed moment."22

As with the Wilde trials—or the Monica Lewinsky affair, for that matter—the trial afforded a public venue for the discussion of sexual matters that were usually not mentioned in public. On the stand Liberace managed his testimony carefully, conveying the "intimacy" of his concert performances onto a new stage. He spoke the offending words plainly, and professed to be standing up for his fans in pressing the libel suit. "At Sheffield when he went on the stage," the Times reported, "there were cries from the audience. They seemed to come from the gallery and were 'Queer' and 'Fairy' and such things as 'Go home, queer.'" Beyfus inquired if these taunts upset Liberace. The pianist replied "Very much, sir; and it upset the audience, too, because I would say a good many people in the audience were embarrassed at hearing these comments."23 He proclaimed that "I have tried in all my performances to inject a note of sincerity and wholesomeness because I am fully aware of the fact that my appeal on television and personal appearances is aimed directly at the family audiences."24

The jury of ten men and two women determined that the pianist had reason to believe that Cassandra's words implied he was a homosexual, and reason to fear they would harm his career. They awarded him the largest libel verdict to date, £8,000, the equivalent of about a quarter of a million dollars in 2010 currency. Afterward, Liberace remarked that he had "laughed all the way to the bank."25

When Forster was a young man, it was fashionably scientific to describe homosexuals as "inverts," men whose soul was effeminate, and whose sexual identity was a distorted reflection of real masculinity.26 Forster never accepted the term, coining the neologism "minority" to describe his sexual identity in his unpublished diary.27 In one sense these intertwined narrative threads—Forster's private story and Liberace's public one—are both tales of inverts, of men forced to camouflage and dissemble, to divide and deny because of their sexual identity. But to gay men in the 1950s, Liberace's trial was a thrilling inversion of Wilde's famous trial. Both Wilde and Liberace were anarchic res who poked fun at, and deployed, bourgeois values to magnify their celebrity. Both were iconically recognizable by their habits of dress. Both were extremely funny and playful. Both used, or attempted to use, the public attention of the Justice system to make a personal case about the power of words to destroy a gay man's career.

But Liberace won the day. The verdict offered an outcome more satisfying than mere reform, revenge. Of course it is not possible to view Liberace's trial as an unalloyed blow for sexual justice. To win the case the great showman had to domesticate his image, mouthing platitudes of self-loathing. But the very cheerfulness of his victory had a salutary appeal. He was not crushed by the encounter with the Justice system, as Wilde had been. Liberace's victorious lawsuit against the "implication that I am homosexual" rewrote the story of Oscar Wilde's trials—the traumatic minatory lesson of Forster's teenage years.

There is no direct evidence of Forster's reaction to the trial. But the very existence of this scrap led me into the wonderland of this complex cultural moment of post-war sexual liberations, and alerted me to Forster's advocacy. We think of queer lives as trafficking in hyperbole, but my experience researching my new biography of Forster has shown the opposite. Again and again a tiny shard of evidence leads to a complex subterranean story.

Both Cassandra and Forster sensed an anarchic power in Liberace's story, a struggle for "the future of civilization." Forster was suspicious of the very idea of civilization, or rather of what he called "the brassy rattle of civilisation so-called." Fifty years earlier, he had written a letter to his friend Florence Barger, celebrating a love affair with an Egyptian man. He thanked her for understanding that this first fully-realized love was as legitimate as heterosexual love stories:

I imagine it is indeed worthy to be thought about; it is such a triumph over nonsense and artificial difficulties: it is a sample of the . . . other triumphs that I am sure come off but of which we hear nothing through the brassy rattle of civilisation so called. . . . When I am with him smoking or talking quietly ahead . . . I see beyond my own happiness and intimacy, occasional glimpses of the happiness of 1000s of others whose names I shall never hear, and I know that there is a great unrecorded history.28

Forster most likely recognized Liberace's rewriting of Wilde's unhappy ending as part of a new counter-narrative. Just about the time of the Liberace trials, he began to revise his long-suppressed Maurice manuscript, drafting an explicit love scene between Maurice and Alec. He began to plan for its posthumous publication, its entrance into a counter-canon. But Forster was also deeply aware that oppression of homosexuals was an ineluctable note of "civilization's brassy rattle." As the Wolfenden Report languished and no law was forthcoming, he composed a "Terminal Note" to the manuscript of Maurice:

Homosexuality

Note in conclusion on a word hitherto unmentioned. Since Maurice was written there has been a change in the public attitude here: the change from ignorance and terror to familiarity and contempt. It is not the change towards which Edward Carpenter had worked. . . . And I . . . less optimistic, had supposed that knowledge would bring understanding. We had not realised that what the public really loathes in homosexuality is not the thing itself but having to think about it. If it could be slipped into our midst unnoticed, legalised overnight by a decree in small print, there would be few protests. Unfortunately it can only be legalised by Parliament, and Members of Parliament are obliged to think or to appear to think. Consequently the Wolfenden recommendations will be indefinitely rejected, police prosecutions will continue, and Clive on the bench will continue to sentence Alec in the dock. Maurice may get off.29

The tug of war over the future of civilization did not resolve with the momentary victory of the Liberace trial. But the subversive voices of gay life had a long history too. Forster had read Roger Casement's Black diaries and Ulysses, Lolita and Giovanni's Room. And just down the street at the local cinema, Elvis Presley, "a handsome boy," sang and danced "most provocatively" in Jailhouse Rock. Joe Ackerley recommended it (PP 338).

Wendy Moffat  

Wendy Moffat is Professor of English at Dickinson College. Her decade in the Forster archives yielded one book with two titles: A Great Unrecorded History: A New Life of E. M. Forster (Farrar Straus and Giroux, 2010) and E. M. Forster: A New Life (Bloomsbury, 2010). She teaches modernism, narrative theory, and history of sexuality.

Notes

1. E.M. Forster, "Notes on the Future of Civilisation," undated manuscript [1950s], Kings College Archive Centre, Cambridge University. Since I first read this manuscript, it has been transcribed for publication in Jeffrey M. Heath, ed., The Creator as Critic and Other Writings by E. M. Forster (Toronto: Dundern Press, 2008) 205-6. Unfortunately, because Forster's hand is so difficult to read, there are errors and omissions in Heath's transcription.

2. Forster, Ibid.

3. Darden Asbury Pyron, Liberace: An American Boy (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2000), xvii; hereafter abbreviated LAA. See also Pyron 222-224; Times (London), June 9-20, 1959: 222-4.

4. (LAA, 212-245). One tabloid published a ribald dig at the pianist in the form of a joke: "The difference between Liberace, Westinghouse, and Christine Jorgenson is that you can be sure if it's Westinghouse" (LAA, 214).

5. Quentin Crisp, The Naked Civil Servant (New York: Holt, Rinehart and Winston, 1977), 167.

6. E. M. Forster to Viscount Samuel, 4 November 1953, quoted in P. N. Furbank, E. M. Forster: A Life (New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, 1978), vol. II: 335, 334; hereafter abbreviated EMF.

7. In the United States, a parallel public campaign sought to expose homosexual men in the civil service and government positions. See David K. Johnson, The Lavender Scare: The Cold War Persecution of Gays and Lesbians in the Federal Government (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2004.)

8. See Peter Wildeblood, Against the Law (London: Weidenfeld and Nicolson, 1956); Edward John Barrington Douglas-Scott-Montagu (Lord Montagu of Beaulieu), Wheels within Wheels: An Unconventional Life (London: Weidenfeld and Nicolson, 2001); and Sheridan Morley, John Gielgud: The Authorized Biography (New York: Simon and Schuster, 2002).

9. Patrick Higgins, Heterosexual Dictatorship: Male Homosexuality in Postwar Britain (London: Fourth Estate, 1996), 288-90. Higgins includes a facsimile of the article, Jeffrey Weeks, Coming Out: Homosexual Politics in Britain from the Nineteenth Century to the Present (London: Quartet, 1990), 163.

10. E.M. Forster, Locked Diary, 27 October 1958, Kings College Archive Centre, Cambridge University. The friend was Harry Daley, a policeman.

11. E. M. Forster, "Society and the Homosexual: A Magistrate's res," the New Statesman, 31 October 1953; Lord Samuels to EMF, 29 November 1953 (EMF, 135).

12. Times (London), 12 June 1959. This is from the account of the civil trial. The first publication of the libel was in the Daily Mirror, 26 September 1956. The testimony that Connor was "terrified" occurred only at the trial.

13. Higgins, Heterosexual Dictatorship, 115. The recommendation was number one of nine.

14. Jeffrey Weeks, in Heterosexual Dictatorship, 156.

15. It applied only to England and Wales, excepted members of the armed services, set the age of consent for homosexuals (at twenty-one) four years above the age of consent for heterosexuals, and denoted "private" space very narrowly. (Since anywhere a third person was likely to be present—whether present or not—was defined as public space, even the interior of one's own home was not always deemed private for the application of the law.) After The Sexual Offenses Act went into effect in 1967, prosecutions of homosexual acts soared. See Jeffrey Weeks, Sex, Politics and Society (London: Longman, 1980); in a strange twist, Wolfenden's son Jeremy told his father he was homosexual before the Committee began its deliberations. Sir John Wolfenden never acknowledged this fact. See Sebastian Faulks, The Fatal Englishman: Three Short Lives (New York: Vintage, 1997) for a brief life of the journalist Jeremy Wolfenden.

16. Peter Parker, Ackerley: A Life of J.R Ackerley (New York: Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 1989), 228-9; hereafter abbreviated PP. This concerns coverage, including J. R. Ackerley's letter in the Spectator, November (20 and 27) and December (4 and 18), 1942.

17. The letter was printed in the Times, 11 December 1959.

18. But Forster reassured his younger friend that he was unafraid; in any case, he preferred "Bobbie's"—a tiny club with a working-class clientele on Dean Street. J.R. Ackerley collection, Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas, Austin.

19. Letter to R. J. Ackerly, c. January 1958, n.d. Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas (Qtd. PP, 338).

20. New York Times, 9 June 1959, 43.

21. Times (London), 12 June 1959.

22. (EMF, 178). This "unguardeed moment" was a pun on horse guards' promiscuity and Plomer's taste for guards as casual partners.

23. Times (London) 12 June 1959.

24. Ibid.

25. (LAA, 168). The first instance of Liberace using this phrase is a letter dated in 1954 to an unknown recipient. But he repeated it as a laugh line in his performances after the Cassandra case. The following year Morgan sat in the witness box at another civil trial. In 1928 he had been prepared to defend Radclyffe Hall's lesbian novel The Well of Loneliness; thirty-two years later, he defended the literary merits of D. H. Lawrence's Lady Chatterley's Lover. The posthumously-published novel became the next test case in Sir Theobald Mathews' latest purity campaign. Forster's defense that Lady Chatterley had "very high literary merit" helped to win the day for Penguin Press. But he could not resist a bit of sardonic commentary: "By the way, did D. H. Lawrence ever do anything for anybody? Now that we have been sweating ourselves to help him, the idea occurs." E. M. Forster to J. R. Ackerley, 4 December 1960, Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas, Austin; E. M. Forster to William Plomer, 4 December 1932, Durham University Archives, Durham, UK.

26. See Joseph Bristow, Sexuality (London: Routledge 1997), 12-46.

27. Forster, Locked Diary, 21 March 1906, King's College Archive Centre, Cambridge University.

28. E. M. Forster to Florence Barger, 25 August 1917, Kings College Archive Centre, Cambridge University; reprinted in P. N. Furbank and Mary Lago, eds., Selected Letters of E. M. Forster (Cambridge: Harvard Belknap Press, 1983) vol. I: 268-69.

29. E.M. Forster, Maurice, Abinger edition (London: Andre Deutsch, 1999), 220.

Project MUSE Journals Volume 17, Number 3, September 2010 The Comedy of Nature: Darwinian Feminism in Virginia Woolf's Between the Acts

Volume 17, Number 3, September 2010

E-ISSN: 1080-6601 Print ISSN: 1071-6068

The Comedy of Nature:
Darwinian Feminism in Virginia Woolf's Between the Acts
Sam See

Woolf's Concentration

I like wine. Air raids much less.

—Virginia Woolf1

In a letter that scholars provisionally date to March 18, 1941, Virginia Woolf explained to her husband Leonard why she was "going mad again." "I begin to hear voices, and cant concentrate," Woolf records: "You see I cant even write this properly. I cant read. What I want to say is that I owe all the happiness of my life to you."2 In the intervening days before she took her life on March 28, Woolf sent a copy of her last novel, Between the Acts , to John Lehmann, managing director of Hogarth Press. Despite his enthusiastic praise for the text, Woolf wrote Lehmann on March 27 to declare that she would continue to revise the novel,3 which she had earlier called "a concentration—a screw" amidst the "many air raids" of World War II and a "concentrated small book" that contained "many varieties of mood" (DVW, 5: 311, 114). The next day, Woolf wrote Leonard a note similar to her letter of March 18—omitting the sentence about her inability to "concentrate"—and drowned herself hours later in the River Ouse.

A writer who believed that "to shut out, to concentrate—that is perhaps—one of the necessary conditions [. . .] of genius," Woolf knew that retaining her concentration was also, by the time she omitted it from her final letter to Leonard, a necessary condition of survival (DVW, 4: 179). World War II escalated the struggle that Woolf had endured throughout her life to retain such focus: numbered 115 and 116 on Hitler's secret arrest list for England, the Woolfs both planned to kill themselves should Hitler invade England, which seemed increasingly plausible during the Blitz (DVW, 5: 165). Contemplating the alternatives of "we in concentration camps, or taking sleeping draughts," Woolf avowed her intention to do the latter or gas herself in her garage rather than submit to Hitler, for "capitulation will mean all Jews to be given up. Concentration camps. So to our garage" (DVW, 5: 292-3). The Nazi concentration camps presented Woolf with two fatal options—taking her own life or having it taken from her—that would eliminate the possibility of concentration altogether.4

At the expense of finishing what she otherwise considered to be a "triumphant" novel, however, Woolf did retain through her final days "a concentration" in the "concentrated [. . .] variety of moods" of Between the Acts, a book that critiques the Nazi regime and that provided Woolf focus during the Blitz (DVW, 5: 340). As her use of the word to describe both her personal attention and her novel's aesthetic suggests, concentration was, for Woolf, not only a state of mind in this period but a medium of aesthetic, ethical, and political agency. Her March 18 letter to Leonard establishes such links as it correlates Woolf's personal facility to "concentrate" with her aesthetic abilities to "write" and "read." The goal of this correlation, she says, is to express her belief in and gratitude for intersubjective bonds: "I owe all the happiness of my life to you."

Woolf's concentration thus highlights a central aesthetic and ethical paradigm in her late work, namely the need to overcome the boundaries of the self in order to sympathize with a world of others, what Natania Rosenfeld calls Woolf's "politics of intersubjectivity."5 While her association of the phrases "to concentrate" and "to shut out" might appear to imply just the opposite, Woolf actually concentrates by shutting out the self, specifically the self's socially-constructed identity. Woolf's concentration is as she says "a screw," a binding agent between subject and object made acutely necessary by the war, during which she wrote that "now's the time to see if the art, or life, creed, the belief in something existing independently of myself, will [. . .] hold good" (DVW, 5: 264). As a transitive verb, "concentrate" requires such selective focus on others: it denotes the fixation of personal faculties on an object, and it can mean bringing a group of objects together.6 For Woolf, these definitions work simultaneously, for she posits in Between the Acts that one must divest oneself of self-identity—threatening but never achieving biological death—in order to create a collectivity that might survive, and in fact prevent, the self-obsessed sources and goals of warfare.

As the force required to screw objects together suggests, however, this ethic troublingly posits that instances of violence by and to the ego yield communal cohesion. Especially in her late work, as Patricia Klindienst Joplin argues, Woolf explores "whether it is possible to constitute an identity, whether as an individual or group, except at the expense of an other."7 In her memoir "A Sketch of the Past" , for example, Woolf records how the Blitz reinforced her belief that "nothing is so much to be dreaded as egotism. Nothing so cruelly hurts the person himself; nothing so wounds those who are forced into contact with it."8 Yet such violence, she had claimed of World War I, can also yield a "whole people [. . .] concentrated on a single point" (DVW, 1: 217), a concentration that Woolf calls during WWII "the community feeling: all England thinking this same thing—this horror of war—at the same moment." Horror like war is prerequisite for collective concentration, she writes, lest come "the lull & one lapses again into private separation" (DVW, 5: 215).

While scholars have examined the politics of community in Woolf's late work—most persuasively as a critique of modernist preoccupations with interiority—they have largely overlooked how Woolf's ethic of self-divestiture hinges on this principle of violence.9 Yet this ethic inheres in another denotation of "concentrate": to strengthen through distillation, even purification.10 Formally and thematically, Woolf's vision of concentration in Between the Acts enacts such violent purification on the model of atavism, or the reversion of biological forms to prior stages of development, an idea popularized in the modernist period by Charles Darwin, whose work Woolf read and wanted to write about during WWII (DVW, 5: 274, 294, 331). Darwin based his theory of descent partially on the evidence of atavistic traits in humans, which he terms "reversions" and "rudiments," the former concept referring to biological structures that reappear during a species' development, the latter referring to obsolete structures that nonetheless endure.11 Together, Darwin writes, "reversionary, as well as the strictly rudimentary, structures reveal the descent of man from some lower form in an unmistakeable manner" (DOM, 1: 130). In his documentation of "reversions to a savage state, from which we are not removed by very many generations" (DOM, 1: 173), Darwin offered one of the most famous violations of anthropocentrism in modern thought. In Between, Woolf extends this violation to a civilization whose efforts at domination betray, and threaten to destroy, its members' collective "lower form."12

Thematically, Woolf creates a concentrated community in this novel by stripping individuals of the pretensions to civilization that constitute individual and national identities alike. Such pretensions structure the novel's premise about a small English village community that gathers in the summer of 1939 at a country estate named Pointz Hall to witness and participate in an annual pageant play meant to celebrate English literary and political history. Woolf stages that play outdoors, however, in a natural setting that vexes the play and causes the audience to realize, as one anonymous character says, "'there's a sense in which we all, I admit, are savages still.'"13 By atavistically despoiling her characters' individual identities, Woolf concentrates them into an unidentified "we."14 As an anonymous portion of the audience muses, "'It's a good day, some say, the day we are stripped naked. Others, it's the end of the day'" (BTA, 106). "Living near to the bone" (DVW, 5: 328), as Woolf described life during the war, Between's characters have no choice about whether to regress: only about whether their submission to that reversion will constitute their civilization's renewal or its death.15

Formally, Woolf enacts this distillation through the novel's direct discourse and objective third-person reportage. Both formal traits detach the narrator (when one appears) and the reader from characters' private lives. This narratological detachment, or stripping away of mediation, explains Woolf's preoccupation with the drama in Between, for the novel form is distinguished by narratological mediation, whereas drama typically forgoes mediation and relates character through dialogue and action. Stripping her novel of a mediating "I" (or any consistent narratological voice), Woolf presents a community in the process of self-divestiture. Such techniques led Woolf to claim that she had "got at a more direct method of summarising relations" (DVW, 5: 200) and found "a new combination of the raw & the lyrical" while writing Between (DVW, 5: 259). Through such aesthetic concentration, the novel formalizes its atavistic thematics.16

Disturbing even on their own terms, Woolf's aesthetic and ethic of concentration run troublingly close to the eugenic logic practiced in the Nazi concentration camps, which Hitler's regime used in a genocidal campaign initiated before and escalated after Woolf's death.17 The Nazis murdered homosexuals, Jews, and other social minorities in an effort to purify the race of degeneracy, a term that arose with evolutionary theory to denote biological forms that were atavistic and/or enervated.18Between adumbrates this genocide, as characters read about murders and imprisonment on the continent, discuss Jewish refugees, and fear invasion as they watch threatening planes fly overhead during the pageant (BTA, 32; 84; 131; 135). Depicting her characters in a universal state of degeneration—"all savages"—but proposing that such degeneration is salvific, Woolf parodies eugenic forms of concentration that endorse material destruction, even as she supports a form of concentration that propagates material difference by distilling social identity. With such parody, as the epigraph above suggests, Woolf employs a relentlessly humorous tone throughout Between that engenders the "variety of moods" that she claimed her "concentrated small book" contained.

A paragraph from the early typescript of Between the Acts exemplifies this strange concatenation of humor and horror in Woolf's principle of concentration:

To some, a snatch of poetry, if it were only the rhyme on a tear-off calendar, was as necessary a part of the toilet as any other; they read as they brushed their teeth. But the concentration necessary was unhygienic; they could no more read poetry by the hour—unless stretched in a sand pit or under a tree with a pine needle for marker, dipping and ceasing, dipping and ceasing—than they could do dumbbell exercises or pray. It was a concentration, a pressure upon the mind—poetry—that turned it to diamond. And how could a pressure like that be maintained without injury to the delicate fibres?

(PH, 50)

Framed within a laughable scene of British gentry reading poetry while brushing their teeth, Woolf's description of concentration, with its parodic attention to hygiene, subverts the Nazis' eugenic logic of purification. For Woolf, concentration upon aesthetic matters is "unhygienic" by normative standards: it requires "dipping and ceasing" into atavistic poses "in a sand pit or under a tree"; it demands a focus that exceeds the boundaries of self-care and must incur "injury to the delicate fibres." Yet such violence to civilized identity may be constructive, Woolf implies, for this "pressure upon the mind" transforms the mind into "diamond."

Although she omits this scene from the novel's final—but for her only provisional—iteration, Woolf uses this simultaneously humorous and disturbing logic of concentration throughout Between the Acts to undermine the egotistical self bent on dominating others with its own sense of identity. Epitomizing one of the novel's refrains, "the laughter died away," Between is riddled with affectively incongruous episodes: reflections on rape inspiring reflections on the weather, a tale of suicide followed by an adult's defending her own immaturity, murder in the name of "a child's game," and a woman (indeed a whole community) who looks "nearly extinct" as she "clapped and laughed loud" (BTA, 40, 42, 45, 16, 31, 68, 65). Such episodes themselves riddle the text's long pageant play, a pastiche of English comedies that fails so miserably that its author repeatedly likens it to death (BTA, 96, 122).

Scholars have long debated about whether such scenes position Between the Acts within the comedic or the tragic mode, yet I argue that Woolf's aesthetic of concentration distills the tragedy of civilization into a comedy of nature.19 Woolf pits the historically subordinate, feminized mode of comedy against the traditionally dominant, masculinized mode of tragedy to create a formal allegory for the novel's feminist politics: as Woolf herself claimed, "when tragedy and comedy collide it is comedy that wins."20 Whereas tragedy classically offers a "change of fortune [that] should be not from bad to good, but, reversely, from good to bad,"21 Woolf's comedy of nature employs the tragic structure of decline as a good: as a submission and return to a Darwinian understanding of nature as infinitely heterogeneous and transformative, one wherein "species are not immutable" but exist in "infinitely varied diversities."22 Distilled to this state of material mutability, homo sapiens might renounce its civilized claim to a static identity and submit to the remarkably "protean and polymorphic" quality that, Darwin believes, characterizes the human species (DOM, 1: 249).23 For Woolf, the transformative possibilities inherent in the atavistic human seem promising in an era tragically committed to ideological stasis.24

When Woolf's character Isa requests a "new plot" in Between the Acts, then, a "plot [that] was only there to beget emotion," Woolf provides one in the form of what Dana Seitler terms the modernist "degeneration narrative," which, "rather than resulting in the closure of the conventional heterosexual love plot or adventure novel, results in the regression of an individual to an atavistic state," such that its plot "regresses as it progresses."25 Refusing a heterosexual telos, Woolf's degenerative comedy presents a complementary mode to what Michael North calls the 20th-century's "machine-age comedy," a historically unprecedented form inspired by that century's innovations in mechanical reproduction, for the post-Darwinian comedy of nature produces difference through a variety of reproductive and non-reproductive means.26 On the evidence of productive forces like the "spontaneous variations of instincts," in fact, Darwin argues that it is "certainly an error" to suppose "that all variations are connected with the act of sexual reproduction" (OS, 245, 32). Whereas the machine's comedy emerges from a confusion between the mechanical and the natural, nature's comedy emerges from their disarticulation: from the disarticulation of any identification, in fact, wherein production could be mistaken for reproduction alone.27

In Between the Acts, Woolf represents such potentially non-reproductive diversities in a queer social world that arguably realizes the "anonymous and secret Society of Outsiders" that, she envisions in Three Guineas , might t fascism pacifically by rejecting nationalist motivations.28 The "many variety of moods" that permeate Between's queer world may accordingly be synthesized as camp, an aesthetic whose resistance to definition itself exemplifies the novel's affective indeterminacy.29 In her 1964 essay "Notes on 'Camp,'" nonetheless, Susan Sontag provides some consistent traits of the aesthetic that bear relation to Between: that camp "is alive to a double sense in which some things can be taken"; that camp "corrupts" and "appreciates vulgarity"; and that "camp and tragedy are antitheses," for camp "proposes a comic vision of the world" and evinces "love for human nature."30 Reinforcing Jed Esty's insight that Between "represents a group's wish to avoid collective identity as a positive feature of its collective identity," the novel's camp aesthetic corrupts individual and national identities to propose a communal ethic of "human sympathy," of "love for human nature."31

In contemporary theoretical accounts of queer experience, however, feelings like camp are characteristically set in opposition to scientific understandings of nature, as is queerness generally. Writes Sontag, "camp objects, and persons, contain a large element of artifice. Nothing in nature can be campy" ("Notes," 55). Upsetting such critical orthodoxies, Between depicts queer feelings like camp as natural on the Darwinian logic that nature itself is queer, or endlessly transformative and defiant of material or conceptual normativity.32 In contrast to the green nail polish and mangy fur coat that adorn this period's most famously campy character, Christopher Isherwood's Sally Bowles, the novel offers a distilled version of camp that, with its emphasis on forms of concentration, including biological and cultural atavism, might be called concentrated camp.33 This term encapsulates how Woolf enacts in form precisely the ethic that she propounds in content: she strips an aesthetic typically laden with civilized trappings to its bare material core—the unidentified, feeling body—just as she proposes that European civilization degenerate to a social mode of material interconnection before the artifice of identity takes on such force that it eradicates materiality altogether.

As Steve Lipman and Viktor Frankl record, a related form of humor pervaded the atavistic conditions of the concentration camps themselves, where prisoners "found humor, sometimes sardonic humor, in all aspects of their disrupted existence" as a way to "embrac[e] the wider cycles of life and death" and to reject "false illusions" and "artificial optimism."34 Woolf similarly disparaged wartime's artificial feelings: she mourned that "most people are numb & have surface optimism" derived from "the emotional falsity" of "that dreary false cheery hero-making strain" that emerged in German and British war propaganda (DVW, 231, 292). For Woolf, such propaganda sanitized war's horror under the patronizing, and paternalistic, guise of heroism: "I dont like any of the feelings war breeds: patriotism; communal &c, all sentimental & emotional parodies of our real feelings" (DVW, 302). With her camp aesthetic, Woolf parodies these "emotional parodies" themselves to foil the horror that Nazi propaganda rationalized under the name of health and British propaganda under the name of heroism. Such parodies might, she hoped, shock the wartime community out of its numb optimism and transform Hitler's oppressive concept of "nature as guarantor of unchanging order" on the Darwinian logic that nature is the guarantor of a changing order.35 If camp "refashion[s] as a weapon of attack an oppressive identity inherited as subordination," Woolf's concentrated camp refashions nature as guarantor of the chance that queer lives might proliferate beyond eugenic concentration.36

Darwinian Feminism

Laughter is an indispensible tool in deconstructions of the bio-politics of being female.

Suspicion and irony are basic to feminist reinscriptions of nature's text.

—Donna Haraway, Primate Visions: Gender,Race, and Nature in the World of Modern Science37

As detailed in A Room of One's Own and Three Guineas, Woolf characteristically described war in gendered terms, viewing fascism as a product of European patriarchy.38 As we will see, Woolf also characteristically described humor as women's best weapon against such forces. With Between's obscene camp, she expands this feminist politic to the realm of queer aesthetics. In the October 1938 letter in which she announces her first work on the novel, in fact, Woolf claims that she is "going to write a comedy about" the idea "that marriage [. . .] reduces one to a damnable servility."39 By making such reduction humorous, Woolf aims, as Christine Froula argues, "to form a radical public to whom women artists, like Joyce and Proust, can 'say everything,'" including, as Rebecca Walkowitz aptly puts it, that "one must risk being bad—uncertain, inconsistent, unsuccessful—in order to keep being good."40

Woolf's attempt to be good with bad aesthetics—a definition of camp itself—is cause to reassess what some have deemed her pacifism and passivity in Between.41 As Pamela Robertson argues in her unprecedented analysis of female camp, "camp offers a slightly different model of negotiation to account for the overlap between passivity and activity in a viewer who sees through, simultaneously perhaps, one mask of serious femininity and another mask of laughing femininity."42 In a position of active passivity, Woolf's characters present a frighteningly comedic response to war: submitting to degradation, not just to martial violence but to natural violence, including the queerly sadomasochistic pleasures of sex. Such sexual submission, Leo Bersani writes, offers "the terrifying appeal of a loss of the ego, of a self-debasement" that, by shattering the ego's "sacrosanct value of selfhood," may also prevent "sexuality [from] becoming a struggle for power."43

In Between the Acts, this degradation emerges through evolutionary tropes of atavism that derive from Darwin's theories of natural selection and variation in, among other texts, The Origin of Species (1859; 1872), The Variation of Animals and Plants under Domestication , and the first volume of The Descent of Man, and Selection in Relation to Sex . Woolf offers these atavistic tropes in earnest; the parodic element of her evolutionary art derives from Darwin's misogynist renderings of sexual selection in the second volume of Descent. Claims like the following, for example, have long made the idea of a Darwinian feminism seem like a contradiction in terms:

Man is more powerful in body and mind than woman, and in the savage state he keeps her in a far more abject state of bondage than does the male of any other animal; therefore it is not surprising that he should gain the power of selection. Women are everywhere conscious of the value of their beauty; and when they have the means, they take more delight in decorating themselves with all sorts of ornaments than do men.

(DOM, 2: 371-2)

Whereas most of Descent's second volume details how sexual selection works on the logic that females are attracted to their more beautiful male counterparts (DOM, 2: 78), Darwin reserves this reductive characterization of beauty-conscious females for the human species, perhaps under the pressure of Victorian gender standards. Regardless of his motivations, Darwin makes beauty, rather than any other aesthetic state, the paradigm of sexual reproduction amongst all species, and he depicts all females in the thrall of males, whether to their beauty or their power. For homo sapiens, Darwin's alarming conclusion from these explorations is that "man has ultimately become superior to woman" (DOM, 2: 328)—a conclusion upon which Hitler seizes in his eugenic practices.

In his rhetoric against degeneration, which Woolf followed assiduously on the BBC and in newspapers (DOM, 5: 245, 263), Hitler declares war against the unsanitized and degenerate on the Darwinian logic that, as he writes in Mein Kampf (1925-6), "every historical event in the world is nothing more nor less than a manifestation of the instinct of racial self-preservation."44 Within the eugenic programs that he endorsed to eliminate degeneracy, programs including forced sterilization and state-run marriages, Hitler aimed to prevent women from working and to subjugate them into maternal roles, for every girl, he averred, "is one day to be a mother" (MK, 376). Coupled with his attempt to eliminate homosexuals, whom he considered as "infectious and as dangerous as the plague," Hitler's campaign against non-reproductive women attempted to institutionalize reproductivity as the only natural state of sexual being.45

True to his pseudo-Darwinian rhetoric, Hitler calls upon "Nature" to justify his eugenic programs, citing it as a model of "selective breeding" (MK, 39). While Darwin does flirt with eugenic ideals at the end of Descent's second volume, he more consistently holds that nature is not a selective breeder but a random collection of "dimly understood laws of variation [that] are infinitely complex and diversified" and whose "number and diversity of inheritable deviations of structure, both those of slight and those of considerable physiological importance, are endless" (DOM, 2: 403; OS, 34). Natural selection cannot work in states of homogeneity, Darwin writes, for "the possibility of selection coming into action rests on variability," such that "close interbreeding, by lessening [species'] vigour and fertility, aids in their final extinction."46 Deploying Darwin's invariant theory of sexual selection to the point of obfuscating his theories of natural selection and variability, Hitler perverts evolutionary theory to legislate its laws, especially the laws of sexual nature, despite his claim that "man must not ever fall into the error of thinking that he was ever meant to be the lord and master of Nature."47

Owing in part to such deployments of Darwin's science of gender, Woolf was generally suspicious of science, and she particularly distrusted her doctors, many of whom were active in the eugenics field.48 Nonetheless, she read more sexological work in the last three years of her life than any period theretofore, including not just Darwin but "Victorian psychology" that denigrated women (TG, 132).49 In portions of Between the Acts, Woolf earnestly condemns this field's doctrine about women's "bondage" to men, to a cult of beauty, and to the preservation of hygiene.
